{{Other people|Harold Brown}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Harold Pitney Brown | honorific_suffix = | image = File:Harold Pitney Brown engineer 1857 1932.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | nationality = [[American people|American]] | citizenship = | birth_name = | birth_date = September 16, 1857 | birth_place = [[Janesville, Wisconsin]] | death_date = 1944 (aged 86–87) | death_place = [[Volusia, Florida]] | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | education = self-educated | spouse = | parents = | children = | module = {{ infobox engineering career | discipline = [[Electrical engineer]] | institutions = | practice_name = | employer = [[Western Electric|The Western Electric Manufacturing Company of Chicago]], [[Brush Electric Company]], [[Consultant|Private consultant]] | significant_projects = | significant_design = | significant_advance = | significant_awards = [[Edward Longstreth Medal]] }} | signature = | signature_alt = }} '''Harold Pitney Brown''' (September 16, 1857, Janesville, Wisconsin – 1944 Volusia, Florida){{dubious|date=May 2015}} was an American [[electrical engineer]] and inventor known for his [[activism]] in the late 1880s against the use of [[alternating current]] for [[electric lighting]] in New York City and around the country (during the "[[War of Currents]]"). Brown was mostly self-educated, working for several companies in the fledgling electrical field before striking out on his own, working on his own inventions as well as hiring himself out as a consultant. After several deaths were caused by alternating current arc lighting lines in New York City, Brown came to prominence in June 1888, claiming in the press and then in public meetings that AC was more deadly than [[direct current]] and that the arc lighting companies were cutting corners and using AC to save money at the cost of public safety. He conducted public demonstrations (electrocuting animals with AC) then lobbied around the country trying to limit AC transmission line voltages to 300 volts, tactics which had him using the press to directly attack the country's largest AC equipment manufacturer, [[Westinghouse Electric]]. He also pushed to have the first [[electric chair]], which was being developed by the state of New York, be powered with AC current, provided by Westinghouse generators he had surreptitiously acquired.{{cite web |url=http://www.crimemuseum.org/library/execution/electrocution.html |title=Electrocution |publisher=Crimemuseum.org |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130519181253/http://www.crimemuseum.org/library/execution/electrocution.html |archivedate=2013-05-19 |df= }} His involvement in these events is controversial since he was working parallel with (some documents show colluded with) [[Thomas Edison]], showing a preference for Edison's [[direct current]] power system and advocating for severe restrictions on AC power systems that would put Edison's competitors at a disadvantage.Jill Jonnes, Empires Of Light: Edison, Tesla, Westinghouse, And The Race To Electrify The World, Random House - 2004, page 165-169 ==Biography== Harold P Brown was born in Janesville, Wisconsin on September 16, 1857, the son of General Theodore F. Brown and Frances Brown. His father was in the [[American Civil War]] and received an honorary rank of brigadier general for his role in the [[Battle of Kennesaw Mountain]]. Harold Brown graduated [[Chicago High School]] in 1876 and prepared to enroll in mining engineering courses at [[Harvard]] but was unable to since the [[great Chicago fire]] of 1871 had left his family in reduced circumstances. After high school he was employed at the [[Western Electric|Western Electric Manufacturing Company of Chicago]] working on development and manufacturing of electrical devices, including Edison's [[electric pen]] duplicating machine, from 1876 to 1879. From 1879 to 1884 he worked for [[Brush Electric Company]] in charge of designing and installing their [[Arc lamp|arc light]]ing systems. From 1884 to 1887 he operated his own electrical consulting business, Brown Electric Company, where he worked in inventing improved arc lighting equipment.[https://books.google.com/books?id=ukE_AQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA742&ots=ouQ8DuTr3q&dq=%22harold%20p%20brown%22%20brush%20born&pg=PA742#v=onepage&q=%22harold%20p%20brown%22%20brush%20born&f=false Electric Railway Review, Volume, 1895, "Harold P Brown", page 742-743] Brown moved to New York in 1887 and worked as consultant for the New York and Westchester Railroad, Edison General Electric, and consulted on the development of the electric chair with Governor [[David B. Hill]] and the State of New York. He also did consulting work for the City of Newark, Dayton Ohio Buffalo Electric Rail Line, and the Louisville Electric Rail Line. Up through 1912 he invented and manufactured a plastic rail bond electric contact alloy and went on to invent and manufactured a method of applying concrete with compressed air or steam.[https://books.google.com/books?id=ukE_AQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA742&ots=ouQ8DuTr3q&dq=%22harold%20p%20brown%22%20brush%20born&pg=PA742#v=onepage&q=%22harold%20p%20brown%22%20brush%20born&f=false Electric Railway Review, Volume, 1895, "HAROLD P BROWN" page 742-743] Brown was awarded the [[Edward Longstreth Medal]] of the [[Franklin Institute]] in 1899.{{cite web |url=http://www.fi.edu/winners/show_results.faw?gs=&ln=&fn=&keyword=&subject=&award=LONG+&sy=1898&ey=1900&name=Submit |title=Franklin Laureate Database - Edward Longstreth Medal 1899 Laureates |publisher=[[Franklin Institute]] |accessdate=November 14, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222041126/http://www.fi.edu/winners/show_results.faw?gs=&ln=&fn=&keyword=&subject=&award=LONG+&sy=1898&ey=1900&name=Submit |archivedate=February 22, 2014 |df= }} == Anti-AC crusade == {{further|War of Currents}} [[File:Blizzard 1888 01.jpg|thumb|right|The myriad of telephone, telegraph, and AC power lines over the streets of New York City in the [[Great Blizzard of 1888]]. A boy killed by a shorted AC line caused by this storm was one of the cases cited by Brown.]] After a series of deaths in New York caused by the tangle of pole mounted high voltage (up to 6000 volt) alternating current lines Brown came to public prominence when he wrote a letter to the ''[[New York Post]]'' on June 5, 1888 describing the overhead lines as a public menace stating:
The only excuse for the use of the fatal alternating current is that it saves the company operating it [AC] from spending a larger sum of money for the heavier copper wires which are required by the safe incandescent systems. That is, the public must submit to constant danger from sudden death, in order that a corporation may pay a little larger dividend.
His crusade brought him to the attention of inventor [[Thomas Edison]] who was becoming engaged in a [[propaganda]] campaign against alternating current companies including [[Westinghouse Electric Company]] in what would come to be called the [[War of currents]]. Edison lent Brown the uses of his [[West Orange, New Jersey]] laboratory to prove his claims against alternating current. After much experimentation killing a series of dogs, Brown held a public demonstration on July 30 in a lecture room at [[Columbia University|Columbia College]]Howard B. Rockman, Intellectual Property Law for Engineers and Scientists, John Wiley - 2004, page 469 where he demonstrated that up to 1000 volts of DC would not kill a dog while 300 volts of AC would kill. He went on to support legislation to control and severely limit AC installations and voltages (to the point of making it an ineffective power delivery system). The legislation was unsuccessful but another bill to move AC lines underground in New York City, put forward before Brown's campaign, passed in 1889 after a further series of highly publicized deaths that year caused by alternating current. ===Involvement in the electric chair=== {{See also|Electric chair}} [[File:Harold Pitney Brown edison electrocute horse 1888 New York Medico-Legal Journal vol 6 issue 4.png|thumbnail|Harold Brown's December 1888 demonstration of the killing power of AC at Thomas Edison's West Orange laboratory (as depicted in [[Scientific American]]).]] At the same time that Brown was campaigning against alternating current a New York state bill replacing [[hanging]] with electrocution was signed into law (June 4, 1888) and set to go into effect on January 1, 1889. A [[Buffalo, New York]] dentist named [[Alfred P. Southwick]] had been developing a method using a device similar to a dental chair, an execution device referred to as the [[electric chair]].Craig Brandon The Electric Chair: An Unnatural American History page 24 The law did not specify the type of current to use, or the means, so the New York Medico-Legal Society, an informal society composed of doctors and lawyers, was given the task of working out the details. Committee head [[Frederick Peterson]], a [[neurologist]] who had assisted in the dog electrocutions at Columbia College, enlisted Brown's services as a consultant.Richard Moran, Executioner's Current: Thomas Edison, George Westinghouse, and the Invention of the Electric Chair, Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group - 2007, page 102 Brown set up an experiment at Edison's West Orange laboratory on December 5, 1888 with members of the press, members of the Medico-Legal Society, the chairman of the death penalty commission, and Thomas Edison looking on. Brown used alternating current for all of his tests on animals larger than a human, including 4 calves and a lame horse, all dispatched with 750 volts of AC.Mark Essig, Edison and the Electric Chair: A Story of Light and Death, Bloomsbury Publishing USA - 2009, pages 152-155 Based on these results the Medico-Legal Society recommended the use of 1000-1500 volts of alternating current for executions and newspapers noted the AC used was half the voltage used in the power lines over the streets of American cities. Westinghouse criticized this test as a skewed self-serving demonstration by Brown, who was again accused of being in the employ of Edison. Brown refuted the claims and even challenged Westinghouse to an electrical "duel," with Brown agreeing to be shocked by ever increasing amounts of DC power if Westinghouse would submit himself to the same amount of increasing AC power (first to quit loses).Craig Brandon The Electric Chair: An Unnatural American History page 82 Westinghouse declined the offer. Neither Edison, Westinghouse, nor Westinghouse's chief AC rival, [[Thomson-Houston Electric Company]], wanted their equipment to be used in an execution but Brown colluded with Edison Electric and Thomson-Houston to surreptitiously acquire three Westinghouse AC generators to power the first electric chair.[https://books.google.com/books?id=1EOgAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA195&lpg=PA195&dq=harold+brown++%22edison+and+Thomson-Houston%22&source=bl&ots=MCyHZu6jpl&sig=HFWkiD5BYg36i6IDKUe4t1KwyIE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=JwDtVMGWNcucgwS24oCQCQ&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=harold%20brown%20%20%22edison%20and%20Thomson-Houston%22&f=false Mark Essig, Edison and the Electric Chair: A Story of Light and Death, Bloomsbury Publishing - 2005, pages 190-195] Brown would continually claim he had no actual association with Edison although an August 1889 ''New York Sun'' story published letters stolen from Brown's office that seemed to show Brown was receiving directions from, and being paid by, the Edison company as well as Thomson-Houston, including the story on the acquisition of the Westinghouse AC generators.[http://www.inventionandtech.com/content/inventing-electrocution-1?page=show James F. Penrose, Inventing Electrocution, inventionandtech.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225055821/http://www.inventionandtech.com/content/inventing-electrocution-1?page=show |date=2015-02-25 }} ==Publications== * [https://books.google.com/books?id=uI05AQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA361&ots=LX57WWrgTN&dq=New%20York%20Post%20Brown%20%22The%20only%20excuse%20for%20the%20use%20of%20the%20fatal%20alternating%20current%20is%20that%20it%20saves%22&pg=PA360#v=onepage&q=New%20York%20Post%20Brown20%22The%20only%20excuse%20for%20the%20use%20of%20the%20fatal%20alternating%20current%20is%20that%20it%20saves%22&f=false Harold P. Brown's "''To The Editors Of The Evening Post:''" letter from the ''New York Post'' June 5, 1888 (republished on page 860 of THE ELECTRICAL ENGINEER, August 1888)] or easier [http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn83030384/1888-06-05/ed-1/seq-7/] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=9XQEAAAAMAAJ&dq=Electrical%20Distribution%20of%20Heat%2C%20Light%20and%20Power&pg=PP7#v=onepage&q=Electrical%20Distribution%20of%20Heat,%20Light%20and%20Power&f=false "Electrical Distribution of Heat, Light and Power WITH PARTIAL LIST OF DEATHS FROM ELECTRICAL LIGHTING APPARATUS" by Harold Pitney Brown, John Murray Mitchell - 1889] * [https://www.jstor.org/stable/25101892?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents "The New Instrument of Execution" by Harold P. Brown, The North American Review Vol. 149, No. 396 (Nov., 1889), pp. 586-593 (jstor.org)] {{Portalbar|Animal rights}} ==References== * [https://books.google.com/books?id=ukE_AQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA742&ots=ouQ8DuTr3q&dq=%22harold%20p%20brown%22%20brush%20born&pg=PA742#v=onepage&q=%22harold%20p%20brown%22%20brush%20born&f=false Electric Railway Review, Volume, 1895, "HAROLD P BROWN" page 742-743] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=qFc-AQAAIAAJ&pg=PR49&lpg=PR49&dq=84+Designer+special+apparatus+in+charge+of+erection+of+power+and+elec+Brash+Elec+Co&source=bl&ots=JRszBOVqv1&sig=UgxlsqAsg4Wj378csIpR_3WUo18&hl=en&sa=X&ei=RAVQVdz9Gci1ggSi2IGICA&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=84%20Designer%20special%20apparatus%20in%20charge%20of%20erection%20of%20power%20and%20elec%20Brash%20Elec%20Co&f=false Mining and Metallurgy: Published Monthly by the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, Issue 153, American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers - 1919, page xlix] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=nD4MAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA196&lpg=PA196&dq=Harold+P.+Brown+dead+87+brush&source=bl&ots=iSrGLWnnwf&sig=7H5C7mq6G_zGwBSk04QGxb2we-k&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1utQVbr9JoKvggSv2IC4Bw&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=Harold%20P.%20Brown%20dead%2087%20brush&f=false Who's who in Engineering, Volume 1, edited by John William Leonard, Winfield Scott Downs, M. {{Underlinked|date=April 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} The '''International Agreement for the suppression of the White Slave Traffic''' is a series of anti–[[human trafficking]] treaties, the first of which was first negotiated in Paris in 1904. It was one of the first multilateral treaties to address issues of slavery and human trafficking. The [[1926 Slavery Convention|Slavery, Servitude, Forced Labour and Similar Institutions and Practices Convention of 1926]] and the [[International Convention for the Suppression of the Traffic in Women of Full Age]] of 1933 are similar documents.
==1904 treaty== The initial treaty was concluded in Paris on 18 May 1904 and came into force on 18 July 1905.<ref>[http://www1.umn.edu/humanrts/instree/whiteslavetraffic1904.html umn.edu: Text of 'INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENT FOR THE SUPPRESSION OF THE "WHITE SLAVE TRAFFIC"'] at the [http://www1.umn.edu/humanrts/ University of Minnesota Human Rights Library]</ref> A total of 26 states ratified the original 1904 treaty.
==1910 treaty== Five years after the treaty came into force, it was re-negotiated in Paris and concluded on 4 May 1910.<ref>[http://www1.umn.edu/humanrts/instree/whiteslavetraffic1910.html umn.edu: Text of 'INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION FOR THE SUPPRESSION OF THE WHITE SLAVE TRAFFIC']</ref> The 1910 treaty came into force on 5 July 1920. A total of 41 states ratified the 1910 treaty.
==1949 Protocol== In 1949 in [[Lake Success, New York]], a Protocol was negotiated which amended and updated both the 1904 and the 1910 treaties. The Protocol was concluded on 4 May 1949 and came into force on the same date. The resulting amended treaties came into force on 21 June 1951 (1904 version) and 14 August 1951 (1910 version) and . As of 2013, 33 states have ratified the amending Protocol and the amended 1949 versions of the treaties have 54 state parties.

'''Jonathan Lee Riches''' (born December 27, 1976) is a former federal prisoner (inmate #40948-018)<ref>[http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=NameSearch&needingMoreList=false&LastName=Riches&Middle=Lee&FirstName=Jonathan&Race=U&Sex=U&Age=&x=335&y=297 Federal Bureau of Prisons Inmate Locator] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929103045/http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=NameSearch&needingMoreList=false&LastName=Riches&Middle=Lee&FirstName=Jonathan&Race=U&Sex=U&Age=&x=335&y=297 |date=2007-09-29 }} Accessed October 3, 2007.</ref> known for the many [[lawsuits]] he has filed in various United States district courts.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,293268,00.html South Carolina inmate hits Michael Vick with '$63,000,000,000 Billion Dollar' lawsuit alleging Al Qaeda ties] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017043835/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,293268,00.html |date=2007-10-17 }} [[Fox News]]. (August 15, 2007) Accessed October 2, 2007.</ref> Riches was incarcerated at [[Federal Medical Center, Lexington|Federal Medical Center]], [[Lexington, Kentucky]], for [[Mail and wire fraud|wire fraud]] under the terms of a [[plea bargain]]. His release date was April 30, 2012.<ref>[http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=NameSearch&needingMoreList=false&LastName=Riches&Middle=Lee&FirstName=Jonathan&Race=U&Sex=U&Age=&x=335&y=297 Federal Bureau of Prisons Inmate Locator] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929103045/http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=NameSearch&needingMoreList=false&LastName=Riches&Middle=Lee&FirstName=Jonathan&Race=U&Sex=U&Age=&x=335&y=297 |date=2007-09-29 }} Accessed February 18, 2012.</ref> He was arrested for violating his federal probation in December 2012, when he left the Eastern District of the state of Pennsylvania without permission. He allegedly drove to Connecticut and impersonated the uncle of [[Adam Lanza]], the shooter in the [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting|Sandy Hook Elementary School incident]].<ref name="sandy hook">{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/27/jonathan-lee-riches-impersonates-adam-lanzas-uncle_n_2370571.html |title=Jonathan Lee Riches Impersonates Adam Lanza's Uncle, 'Jonathan Lanza,' Gets Arrested |publisher=Huffington Post |date=2012-12-27 |accessdate=2013-03-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130101154333/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/27/jonathan-lee-riches-impersonates-adam-lanzas-uncle_n_2370571.html |archive-date=2013-01-01 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
== History == Since January 8, 2006, he has filed over 2600<ref>{{cite news|last=Harold|first=Zack|title=Former inmate alleges Kardashians, rapper Kanye West conspired with terrorists|url=http://www.charlestondailymail.com/policebrfs/201206260068?display=print|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140305013151/http://www.charlestondailymail.com/policebrfs/201206260068?display=print|dead-url=yes|archive-date=March 5, 2014|accessdate=5 March 2014|newspaper=Charleston Daily Mail|date=June 26, 2012|quote=A search on PACER, the U.S. government website for court documents, found more than 2,600 lawsuits filed by Riches and 49 filed by his alias, "Gino Romano."}}</ref> lawsuits in federal district courts across the country,<ref>US Pacer US Party/Case Index Website maintained by the federal courts; search for Jonathan Riches prisoner cases on March 3, 2008 returned 1017 cases.{{original research inline|date=July 2012}}</ref> some of which have received considerable press attention.<ref>[http://blog.washingtonpost.com/offbeat/2007/08/man_of_many_suits_1.html "Man of Many Suits"], Emil Steiner, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' {{dead link|date=April 2016}}</ref> Among the more famous defendants of his lawsuits are [[New England Patriots]] coach [[Bill Belichick]],<ref>[http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/years/2007/1003072belichick1.html Belichick Scandal Widens] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008104209/http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/years/2007/1003072belichick1.html |date=2007-10-08 }} TSG</ref> former [[President of the United States]] [[George W. Bush]],<ref>Howard, Brian. (April 13–19, 2006). [http://www.citypaper.net/articles/2006-04-13/fineprint2.shtml Trial of the century] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071030053702/http://www.citypaper.net/articles/2006-04-13/fineprint2.shtml |date=2007-10-30 }}. ''Apple Insider''. Accessed October 3, 2007.</ref> celebrity blogger [[Perez Hilton]],<ref>{{cite web | title = An Embarrassment Of Riches | url = http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/years/2007/1018071riches1.html | accessdate = October 19, 2007 | website = The Smoking Gun | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071018232753/http://thesmokinggun.com/archive/years/2007/1018071riches1.html | archive-date = 2007-10-18 | dead-url = no | df = }}</ref> [[Somali pirates]],<ref>2008 West Law 612788</ref> and pop star [[Britney Spears]].<ref>{{cite web| website=Contactmusic.com| title=Prison Inmate Seeks Spears Restraining Order| url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news.nsf/article/prison%20inmate%20seeks%20spears%20restraining%20order_1046490| accessdate=October 12, 2007| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013091930/http://www.contactmusic.com/news.nsf/article/prison%20inmate%20seeks%20spears%20restraining%20order_1046490| archive-date=2007-10-13| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref> He also sued the late [[Benazir Bhutto]], [[Pervez Musharraf]], and the [[Immigration and Naturalization Service]] on November 7, 2007, to prevent him from being deported to [[Pakistan]] and [[torture]]d upon his release from prison in March 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.justia.com/cases/featured/california/caedce/2:2007cv02394/169550/ |title=Riches v. Bhutto et al :: Justia Dockets & Filings |publisher=News.justia.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100124215256/http://news.justia.com/cases/featured/california/caedce/2:2007cv02394/169550/ |archive-date=2010-01-24 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> There is no evidence beyond this lawsuit of any attempt to deport Riches.
On April 9, 2008, Riches filed a request for a temporary [[restraining order]] in a US District Court against ''[[Grand Theft Auto]]'' publisher [[Take-Two]], developer [[Rockstar Games]], FCI Williamsburg, and ''Grand Theft Auto'' itself, claiming that the defendants "put me in prison." The inmate stated, "Defendants contributed to Plaintiff committing identity theft. Defendant's games show sex, drugs and violence which offends me." Riches continued, "Defendants put me in prison. I face imminent danger from violent inmates who played Grand Theft Auto who will knock me out and take my gold Jesus cross."<ref name="foxnews">[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,351896,00.html Inmate Files Restraining Order Against 'Grand Theft Auto' Makers] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080424003949/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,351896,00.html |date=2008-04-24 }} ''[[FoxNews.com]]''. Accessed April 20, 2008.</ref>
Riches attempted to intervene as a plaintiff in the [[Madoff investment scandal]], claiming that he "met Bernard Madoff on [[eharmony.com]] in 2001" and taught Madoff [[identity theft]] skills.<ref name="madoff">[http://www.madofftrustee.com/DownloadDocketImage.aspx?Docket=48 Motion to Authorize to intervene under Rule 7042 & Rule 24(A)2, 24(B) filed by Jonathan Lee Riches.]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''Madoff Trustee Site''. Accessed March 26, 2008.</ref>
In May 2009, Riches filed for an injunction against the [[Guinness Book of World Records]], seeking to stop them from listing him as "the most litigious individual in history".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2009/may/23/man-sues-book-over-most-litigious-crown/|title=Man sues book over most-litigious crown|last=Clouse|first=Thomas|publisher=The Spokesman-Review|date=May 23, 2009|accessdate=25 May 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090527083941/http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2009/may/23/man-sues-book-over-most-litigious-crown/|archive-date=2009-05-27|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Guinness spokesperson Sara Wilcox told ''The Huffington Post'' that there was no such listing, and no plan to create one. "'Most litigious man' is not something Guinness World Records has ever monitored as a record category," she said. The action—like the vast majority of Riches' filings—was dismissed.<ref name="sandy hook"/>
Some of Riches' defendants are not even persons subject to suit. These include "[[Adolf Hitler]]'s [[Nazi Party|National Socialist Party]]" and the "13 tribes of Israel."<ref>Emil Steiner, [http://blog.washingtonpost.com/offbeat/2007/08/man_of_many_suits_1.html Man of Many Suits, Jonathan Lee Riches Sues Everyone and Everything]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''Washington Post'', August 23, 2007</ref> One lawsuit, which includes George Bush, also includes another 783 defendants that cover 57 pages. They include [[Plato]], [[Nostradamus]], [[Che Guevara]], [[James Hoffa]], "Various Buddhist Monks," all survivors of the [[Holocaust]], the [[Lincoln Memorial]], the [[Eiffel Tower]], the {{USS|Cole|DDG-67|6}}, the book ''[[Mein Kampf]]'', the [[Garden of Eden]], the [[Roman Empire]], the [[Dark Ages (historiography)|Dark Ages]], the [[Appalachian Trail]], [[Plymouth Rock]], the [[Holy Grail]], [[List of Germanic deities|Nordic gods]], the dwarf planet [[Pluto]], and the entire [[Three Mile Island]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.citypaper.net/articles/2006-04-13/NC_FP_Lawsuit.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523233742/http://archives.citypaper.net/articles/2006-04-13/NC_FP_Lawsuit.pdf |archivedate=2013-05-23 |df= }}</ref>
A number of Riches' lawsuits have been dismissed as being "frivolous, malicious" or for [[Federal Rules of Civil Procedure|failure to state a claim upon which relief could be granted]].<ref name="rankin"/> [[Willis Hunt]], the U.S. District Court Judge who dismissed Riches' suit against Vick as "farcical," opined that his lawsuits were clearly self-promotional. As per [[Title 28 of the United States Code|28]] U.S. Code § 1915(g), he is barred from proceeding [[in forma pauperis]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Riches v. Wooden et al - Document 3|url=http://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/kentucky/kywdce/4:2010cv00078/74185/3|website=Justia|accessdate=5 March 2014|date=2010-06-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140305035859/http://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/kentucky/kywdce/4:2010cv00078/74185/3|archive-date=2014-03-05|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
In July 2018, Riches was indicted by a federal grand jury in Arizona. He is charged with making false statements and other frauds after an attempt to file a lawsuit against [[Gabrielle Giffords]] while posing as [[Jared Lee Loughner]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://tucson.com/news/local/man-accused-of-filing-phony-lawsuit-against-giffords-indicted-in/article_07a4c311-c642-53aa-865e-1d01b77425a2.html|title=Man accused of filing phony lawsuit against Giffords indicted in Tucson federal court|last=Prendergast|first=Curt|date=July 25, 2018|work=Arizona Daily Star|access-date=September 16, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
A collection of Riches' lawsuits was published on April Fools' Day of 2016.<ref>{{Cite book|isbn = 978-1530603831|title = Comes Now the Plaintiff: Selected Lawsuits and Poems|last1 = Riches|first1 = Jonathan|date = April 2016}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox law firm | name = Kingsford Legal Centre | logo = | headquarters = Ground Floor, Law Building, The University of New South Wales, [[Kingsford, New South Wales|Kingsford]], Sydney, Australia | num_offices = | num_lawyers = 5 employed plus secondees, volunteers and interns | num_employees = 11 | practice_areas = Clinical Legal Education, Community Legal Centre: [[City of Botany Bay|Botany Bay LGA]], [[City of Randwick|Randwick LGA]], employment law and discrimination law | key_people = Associate Professor Anna Cody, Director | revenue = <!-- amount (year) --> | date_founded = 1981 | founder = | company_type = | homepage = http://www.klc.unsw.edu.au/ }}
'''Kingsford Legal Centre''' is an Australian not-for-profit legal centre. It is both part of the network of Australian [[Community Legal Centre]]s and provides clinical legal education as part of the [[University of New South Wales]] [[UNSW Faculty of Law|Faculty of Law]].<ref name=AFR20110606>Joanna Mather, "Education Pro bono a bonus for law students", ''[[Australian Financial Review]]'', 6 June 2011, p 28 via Media Monitors Australia Pty Ltd and factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref>
It provides free advice, referrals and ongoing assistance to the residents of the [[Botany, New South Wales|Botany]] and [[Randwick, New South Wales|Randwick]] local government areas, in areas including: employment law, debts, victims compensation and domestic violence as well as a statewide service for discrimination matters. The Centre takes on cases where there is no other source of assistance or where acting for the client will benefit the community by achieving change in the law or government policy.<ref name=a2j_klc>{{cite web|title=Kingsford Legal Centre|url=http://www.accesstojustice.gov.au/agnet/accesstojustice.nsf/wresources/AGNT-8588AK|work=Access to Justice|publisher=Commonwealth of Australia|accessdate=14 November 2011}}</ref><ref name=Oz20081112>Bernard Lane, "UNSW shows the law is an asset", ''The Australian'' (All-round Country edition), 12 November 2008, p 23, via factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref>
== Funding and partnerships == Kingsford Legal Centre receives funding from the Community Legal Services Programme of the New South Wales Legal Aid Commission,<ref name=AFR20110606/> the Commonwealth of Australia through the Attorney-General's Department (Commonwealth Community Legal Services Program, Clinical Legal Education and Family Law)<ref>Guy Healy, "Law students to staff justice clinics", The Australian, 10 March 1999, p 41, via factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref><ref name=McClelland20100108>Australian Government, "Australian Attorney-General announces additional fund to develop, expand Varsity partnerships" (press release), 8 January 2010, copyright of HT Media Limited via factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref><ref name=clsp_cth>{{cite web|title=The Community Legal Services Program |url=http://www.ag.gov.au/www/agd/agd.nsf/Page/Legalaid_CommunityLegalServicesProgram_TheCommunityLegalServicesProgram |work=Legal Aid |publisher=Australian Government, Attorney-General's Department |accessdate=14 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111128080302/http://www.ag.gov.au/www/agd/agd.nsf/Page/Legalaid_CommunityLegalServicesProgram_TheCommunityLegalServicesProgram |archivedate=28 November 2011 |df= }}</ref> and the University of New South Wales Faculty of Law.
It has a partnership with [[Herbert Smith Freehills]] who provide a solicitor on secondment for six months twice a year.<ref name= AFR20090619>James Eyers, "Man of steel and compassion", ''Australian Financial Review'', 19 June 2009, p 46, via Media Monitors Australia Pty Ltd and factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref><ref name=steele>{{cite web|title=Vale Keith Steele (6 April 1951–7 June 2009)|url=http://www.freehills.com/5091.aspx|work=Freehills|publisher=Freehills Pty Limited|accessdate=14 November 2011|date=11 June 2009}}</ref><ref name=SMH20060315>Vickie Smiles, "Services for the needy", ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', 15 March 2006, p 6 (Supplement)</ref>
== International presence ==
Kingsford Legal Centre has appeared before the [[United Nations Human Rights Committee]] in New York<ref name=AFR20090320>James Eyers, "Lack of domestic legislation could hamper bid for seat", ''Australian Financial Review'', 20 March 2009, p 43, via Media Monitors Australia Pty Ltd and factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref> and The [[Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights]] of the United Nations Office at Geneva as an [[NGO]].<ref name=SNS>"Non-Governmental Organizations address Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights on situation in Brazil, Australia and Cambodia", States News Service, 4 May 2009 via factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref>
== Publicised cases and advisings == In 1982, the Centre was consulted by the [[Ethnic Communities' Council of New South Wales]] after the [[Board of Studies|New South Wales Board of Senior School Studies]] made an error in the marking of the [[Higher School Certificate (New South Wales)|Higher School Certificate]] Modern Greek examination which had caused a number of students to miss out on their choice of university admissions.<ref>Andrew Casey, "HSC losers ask for cash: Marking error cost students' courses", ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', 27 May 1982, p 1 via [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Vv5jAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BOcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5839,9536478&dq=kingsford-legal-centre&hl=en Google News] accessed 14 November 2011.</ref>
The Centre took up Australia's first legal claim by a member of the [[stolen generation]].<ref>''Williams v Minister, Aboriginal Land Rights Act 1983'' (Unreported, Supreme Court of NSW) 25 August 1993; ''Williams v Minister, Aboriginal Land Rights Act 1983 [No 1]'' (1994) 35 NSWLR 497; ''Williams v Minister, Aboriginal Land Rights Act 1983 [No 2]'' (1999) 25 Fam LR 86; ''Williams v Minister, Aboriginal Land Rights Act 1983 [No 3]'' (2000) Aust Torts Reports Page 81-78.</ref><ref>Rafael Epstein, [http://www.abc.net.au/pm/stories/s47020.htm "Stolen Generations case result"], Australian Broadcasting Commission ''PM Archive'' 26 August 1999, accessed 14 November 2011.</ref><ref>Debra Jopson, "Stolen Generation Damages Case Rejected", ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', 13 September 2000, p 6, via factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref>
In 2002, Kingsford Legal Centre successfully represented a mother who had suffered workplace discrimination on the grounds of family responsibilities. This case was one a "series of legal victories by trailblazers" in 2002 which clarified the "law protecting working women's rights".<ref>Sherrill Nixon, [http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2002/09/29/1033283388275.html "Trailblazers pay 'in blood' for legal action on rights"], ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' (online edition), 30 September 2002 accessed 14 November 2011.</ref>
In 2003, Kingsford Legal Centre were instructing solicitors in a case before a Full Bench of the [[Australian Industrial Relations Commission]] which "strengthened the rights of thousands of workers who are labelled casuals, but who are effectively permanent part-time staff."<ref name = SMH20030927>Sherrill Nixon, "Casual Staff Rights Bolstered By Waitress's Legal Win", ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', 27 September 2003, p 5 via factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref> A waitress who was engaged by an employer hotel as a casual employee was held to be a "regular and systematic" employee: casual employees were not entitled to sue for unfair dismissal under the then federal law but the ruling gave her, and a large number of persons in similar circumstances, access to redress for unfair dismissal.<ref name = SMH20030927/>
== Awards and honours == The Kingsford Legal Centre, its staff and volunteers have won a number of awards and accorded various honours. These include:
* in October 2011, Michael Steinfeld won the Community Legal Centres NSW (CLCNSW) Award for his 27 years as a volunteer at the Centre<ref>{{cite web|title=Justice Awards|url=http://www.lawfoundation.net.au/justice_awards|publisher=Law and Justice Foundation|accessdate=14 November 2011}}</ref> * in September 2011, Emma Golledge, Principal Solicitor, Kingsford Legal Centre was named the ''Woman Lawyer of the Year in a Community Organisation'' by the [[Women Lawyers’ Association of New South Wales]]<ref>Alex Boxsell, Rachel Nickless and Samantha Bowers, "Women honoured", ''Australian Financial Review'', 30 September 2011, p 42, via Media Monitors Australia Pty Ltd and factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref> * in March 2010, Merinda Dutton, a Teaching Assistant at the Kingsford Legal Centre, won a ''John Koowarta Reconciliation Law Scholarship''<ref>Law Council of Australia, "Indigenous Scholarship Winners an 'Inspiration'" (media release), 19 March 2010 via Australian Associated Press Pty Ltd and factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref> * in October 2007, Anna Cody, Director, Kingsford Legal Centre, was the recipient of the 2007 ''Government or Community Lawyer Award'' from the Women Lawyers’ Association of New South Wales<ref>Hearsay column, Australian Financial Review, 26 October 2007, p 54 via Media Monitors Australia Pty Ltd and factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=NSW Women Lawyers Achievement Awards, 2007 Awards Winner and New Patron|url=http://www.womenlawyersnsw.org.au/content/nsw-women-lawyers-achievement-awards|work=Women Lawyers' Association of NSW|publisher=Women Lawyers' Association of NSW Inc.|accessdate=14 November 2011}}</ref> * in 2001, the Kingsford Legal Centre team won the 2001 ''Australian Award for University Teaching for Law and Legal Studies'' sponsored by ''The Australian'' and funded by the federal Government to recognise outstanding efforts in university teaching<ref name=Oz20011212>Ian Gerard, "Plaudit for outstanding legal effort", ''The Australian'', 12 December 2001, p 24, "The staff of Kingsford Legal Centre have won the 2001 Australian Award for University Teaching for Law and Legal Studies. ... Part of the University of NSW, the centre gives final-year law and social work students the chance to start using their skills for the benefit of the community before they graduate. Students spend time at the centre as part of clinical legal experience offered by the law faculty. The only legal centre attached to a university in NSW, the centre provides legal advice in domestic violence, discrimination, housing, employment, family and criminal law issues. Kingsford is headed by director Frances Gibson; the other award winners include centre co-ordinator Michelle Burrell, Anna Cody, Kate Burns, Vedna Jivan, Kalliope Ktenas and Joanne Moffitt. ... In awarding the prize, the panel of judges commented on the outstanding commitment and teamwork shown by the winners."</ref> * in 1996, the volunteer lawyers, Kingsford Legal Centre were named co-winners for the Randwick district of the ''Herald Australia Day Awards for Community Service 1995''<ref>Adam Harvey, "Drop-in Centre For Desperate Youth Wins Acclaim", ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', 25 January 1996, p 7</ref>
== ''Reality Bites: Street Practice'' == In 2004, the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] broadcast a four-part television series, ''Reality Bites: Street Practice''<ref>{{cite episode | title = Street Practice | series = Reality Bites |credits = A Hilton Cordell production, Producer/director/camera Michael Cordell, Producer Ian Collie | network = [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] }}</ref> which followed a number of young law students undergoing their clinical legal experience at the Kingsford Legal Centre.<ref>Ben Wyld, [http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/09/06/1094322699133.html "Reality Bites: Street Practice, ABC, 8pm"], The Sydney Morning Herald (online edition), 7 September 2004, "Studying law involves wading through mountainous case studies and analysing hypothetical scenarios involving multi-million-dollar companies. Here, 23 students from the University of NSW get a taste of the real thing as they begin a 14-week stint at the university's community legal centre. This fly-on-the-wall series captures the experiences of the wide-eyed students as they apply their knowledge to real cases for the first time. ...</ref><ref>Kerrie Murphy and Evan Williams, "Tuesday{{mdash}}Quick Bites" (review), ''The Australian'', 18 September 2004, p B44, via factiva.com accessed 14 November 2011.</ref>
== Publications == The Kingsford Legal Centre publishes a number of information pamphlets describing its services and outlining key points of common legal advices, an e-Bulletin and other publications including:
* ''Clinical Legal Education Guide'' (to courses offered in Australian Universities), (2014, Kingsford Legal Centre, Sydney) * ''Guide to Indigenous Legal Education'' (2nd ed. 2010, Kingsford Legal Centre, Sydney) * David Nichols, ''From the Roundabout to the Roundhouse - 25 years of Kingsford Legal Centre'', (2006, Kingsford Legal Centre, Sydney) {{ISBN|978-0-9775289-2-9}} * ''Getting off the Referral Roundabout: Effective legal referral'' (DVD and workbook) (2006, Kingsford Legal Centre, Sydney) {{ISBN|978-0-9775289-1-2}} * ''Discrimination Toolkit : Your Guide to Making a Discrimination Complaint'', (2007, Elizabeth Evatt Community Legal Centre, Kingsford Legal Centre and Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales, Sydney) {{ISBN|978-0-646-47-262-1}}

'''Nominative use''', also "nominative fair use", is a legal [[doctrine]] that provides an [[affirmative defense]] to [[trademark]] infringement as enunciated by the [[United States]] [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit]],<ref name=Doellinger>{{cite journal |url=http://www.law.northwestern.edu/journals/njtip/v1/n1/5/Doellinger.pdf |first=Chad J. |last = Doellinger|title=Nominative Fair Use: Jardine and the Demise of a Doctrine | year= 2003|volume=1|issue=1|accessdate=2007-12-02 |format= pdf|journal=Northwestern Journal of Technology and Intellectual Property|publisher=Northwestern University}}</ref> by which a person may use the trademark of another as a reference to describe the other product, or to compare it to their own. Nominative use may be considered to be either related to, or a type of "trademark fair use" (sometimes called "classic fair use" or "statutory fair use"). All "trademark fair use" doctrines, however classified, are distinct from the [[fair use|fair use doctrine in copyright law]]. However, the fair use of a trademark may be protected under copyright laws depending on the complexity or creativity of the mark as a design logo.<ref name='Pratt'>Pratt, Jacqueline Levasseur. "Not All Is Fair (Use) in Trademarks and Copyrights." ''INTA Bulletin'', Vol 67, No 16. International Trademark Association, 15 September 2012. <http://www.inta.org/INTABulletin/Pages/NotAllIsFair(Use)inTrademarksandCopyrights.aspx>. 6 December 2015.</ref>
The nominative use test essentially states that one party may use or refer to the trademark of another if:
# The product or service cannot be readily identified without using the trademark (e.g. trademark is descriptive of a person, place, or product attribute). # The user only uses as much of the mark as is necessary for the identification (e.g. the words but not the font or symbol). # The user does nothing to suggest sponsorship or endorsement by the trademark holder. This applies even if the nominative use is commercial, and the same test applies for [[metatags]].
Furthermore, if a use is found to be nominative, then by the definition of non-trademark uses, it can not dilute the trademark.<ref name="isbn1-57018-313-9">{{cite book |author=David S. Welkowitz |title=Trademark Dilution: Federal, State, and International Law |publisher=BNA Books (Bureau of National Affairs) |location= |year= 2002|isbn=1-57018-313-9 |quote=Since nominative fair uses are nontrademark uses, no dilution can occur|page=325}}</ref>
Nominative use does ''not'' require that ownership of the trademark be acknowledged, for example by use of a sentence such as "UNIX is a registered trademark of The Open Group". Such statements may, however, be required by the terms of a license agreement between the parties, and they may be prudent (and courteous) as a way of preventing misunderstandings or allegations of [[passing off]].
==History of the doctrine== The nominative use doctrine was first enunciated in 1992 by the U.S. [[Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] in ''[[New Kids on the Block v. News America Publishing, Inc.]]''.<ref>''[[New Kids on the Block v. News America Publishing, Inc.]]'', [[Case citation|971 F.2d 302]] ([[9th Cir.]] 1992).</ref> In ''New Kids on the Block'', the court had examined a "[[New Kids on the Block]] [[opinion poll|survey]]" performed by the [[defendant]], and found that there was no way to ask people their opinion of the band without using its name. For instance, one could refer to the Minnesota Twins as "that professional baseball team from Minnesota," but it is much more acceptable to just refer to them by their trade name.<ref name='Pratt' />
ITn ''[[Playboy Enterprises, Inc. v. Welles]]'',<ref>''[[Playboy Enterprises, Inc. v. Welles]]'', [[Case citation|279 F.3d 796]] ([[9th Cir.]] 2002).</ref> where [[Playboy Playmate]] [[Terri Welles]] was sued for using the trademarked term "Playmate of the Year" in a [[Meta keywords|meta keyword]] within the [[HTML]] code of her [[website]]. The court found that Welles had to use the term to completely describe herself, as she had been given that title by the trademark holder. In other words, individuals are not compelled by trademark law to use "absurd turns of phrase" simply to avoid trademark liability.<ref name='Pratt' />
In ''New Kids'' and in ''Playboy v. Welles'', the courts examined older cases, identifying a unifying principle that they then named "nominative use". Among the older cases cited by the Court in ''Playboy v. Welles'' was ''Volkswagenwerk Aktiengesellschaft v. Church'',<ref>''Volkswagenwerk Aktiengesellschaft v. Church'', 411 F.2d 350, 352 (9th Cir. 1969).</ref> in which the Ninth Circuit had ruled that an independent auto repair shop that specialized in repairing Volkswagen cars and mentioned that fact in their advertising was not liable for trademark infringement so long as they did not claim or imply that they had any business relationship with the Volkswagen company. In the case of ''Yue v. MSC Software Corporation'',<ref>''Yue v. MSC Software Corporation'', Case No. 15-cv-5526-PJH (N.D. Cal. 2016).</ref> the Northern District of California held that the nominative fair use defense is a burden-shifting defense properly decided at the summary judgment stage and would be premature to raise in a motion to dismiss.
==See also== * [[Fair use (U.S. trademark law)]]

{{more references|date=March 2014}} The '''Passivhaus-Institut (PHI)''' is responsible for promoting and maintaining the '''[[Passive House|Passivhaus]]''' building program.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/edp-property/what-is-a-passivhaus-1-5642141|title=The homes on the rise in Norfolk, but what is a Passivhaus?|last=Thomson|first=Emily|work=Eastern Daily Press|access-date=2018-08-07|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.enbausa.de/daemmung/aktuelles/artikel/passivhaeuser-halten-sommerhitze-gut-stand-6006.html|title=Passivhäuser halten Sommerhitze gut stand|work=EnBauSa News: Energetisch Bauen und Sanieren|access-date=2018-08-07|language=de}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://chicago.cbslocal.com/2018/02/05/energy-efficient-home-hyde-park-passivhaus-institut/|title=Chicago's Most Energy Efficient Home Resides In Hyde Park|date=2018-02-05|access-date=2018-08-07|work=CBS Local Chicago|language=en}}</ref> The ''"Passivhaus Institute"'' was founded in 1996, and is based and active in [[Darmstadt, Germany]].
The English spelling was used for the Passive House Institute US (PHIUS) when it formed in 2007 <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.phius.org/about/mission-history|title=Mission & History: Passive House Alliance U.S.|website=www.phius.org|access-date=2018-05-04}}</ref> originally under the umbrella of the Passivhaus Institute. The two separated in 2012.
Though PHI and PHIUS [[sustainable design]] standards are different, they both share common goals for drastic [[energy conservation]] and carbon reduction through [[Sustainable architecture]] design techniques and specifications to create [[Low-energy house]]s and other structures with [[Low energy building]] practices for the public benefit worldwide.

{{Infobox person |birth_date={{birth date and age|1949|11|15}} | education = Ph.D. [[University of Chicago]] 1976 MA University of Chicago 1972 BA [[Syracuse University]] 1971 | occupation = President of [[Gratz College]], Greater Philadelphia, PA }} '''Paul Finkelman''' (born November 15, 1949, in [[Brooklyn]], New York) is an American legal [[historian]], who in 2017 became President of [[Gratz College]], [[Melrose Park, Pennsylvania]] (the oldest independent institution of Jewish learning in the United States).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gratz.edu/news/dr-paul-finkelman-appointed-college-president-gratz-college-board-governors|title=Dr. Paul Finkelman Appointed College President By Gratz College Board of Governors {{!}} Gratz College|website=www.gratz.edu|language=en|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> He has written or edited numerous articles, monographs, and reference books in American legal history, particularly concerning slavery, as well as analyzed various topics on broadcast media.
==Education== Finkelman grew up in [[Watertown, New York]], where he attended public schools. He received his undergraduate degree in [[American studies]] from [[Syracuse University]] in 1971, and his master's degree and doctorate in American history from the [[University of Chicago]] in 1972 and 1976. At Chicago, he was a student of [[Stanley Nider Katz]] and [[John Hope Franklin]] and a contributor to the volume, ''The Facts of Reconstruction: Essays in Honor of John Hope Franklin,'' edited by Eric Anderson & Alfred A. Moss, Jr. (Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, c.1991). Finkelman was also a Fellow in Law and Humanities at [[Harvard Law School]], 1982–83.
==Academic positions and honors== Finkelman has held many positions teaching law and history including at [[Albany Law School]] (President William McKinley Distinguished Professor of Law and Public Policy and Senior Fellow in the Government Law Center), [[University of Tulsa College of Law]] (Chapman Distinguished Professor of Law, 1999–2006), [[University of Akron School of Law]] (John F. Seiberling Professor, 1998–99), [[Cleveland-Marshall College of Law]] (Baker & Hostetler Visiting Professor, 1997–98), [[Hamline Law School]] (Distinguished Visiting Professor, spring 1997), [[University of Miami]] (Charlton W. Tebeau Visiting Research Professor, 1996), [[Chicago-Kent College of Law]] (fall 1995), [[Virginia Tech]] (1992–95), [[Brooklyn Law School]], (1990–92), [[Binghamton University|SUNY Binghamton]] (1984–1990), [[University of Texas]] (1978–84), [[University of Texas Law School]] (Spring 1982), [[Washington University]] (Andrew W. Mellon Faculty Fellow, 1977–78) and [[University of California, Irvine]] (1976–77).
He received fellowships from the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]], the [[American Philosophical Society]], the [[Library of Congress]], [[Yale University]], [[Harvard Law School]], and the [[American Council of Learned Societies]]. American institutions at which he was a resident scholar include: [[Transylvania University]], [[Mississippi State University]], the [[University of Seattle]] School of Law, and [[St. Bonaventure University]]. In 2009, Finkelman gave the Nathan A. Huggins lectures at the W.E.B. DuBois Center at Harvard University. His 2018 book ''Supreme Injustice: Slavery in the Nation's Highest Court''<ref>{{cite book|last1=Finkelman|first1=Paul|title=Supreme Injustice: Slavery in the Nation's Highest Court|date=2018|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|isbn=9780674051218}}</ref> was based on these lectures. Since 2001, Finkelman has been a Distinguished Lecturer for the [[Organization of American Historians]]. He received the Joseph L. Andrews Award from [[American Association of Law Libraries]] in 1986,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aallnet.org/mm/Member-Resources/AALLawards/award-jla.html |title=Joseph L. Andrews Legal Literature Award |website=Aallnet.org |date= |accessdate=September 18, 2016}}</ref> and in 1995, was named Historian of the Year by the Virginia Social Science Association.{{Citation needed|date = July 2015}}
Finkelman has also lectured on behalf of the U.S. State Department in Colombia, Germany, Japan, and China. He spent part of the fall 2008 semester at [[Osaka University]] in Japan, as a visiting research scholar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paulfinkelman.com/ |accessdate=February 18, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130105080656/http://www.paulfinkelman.com/|title=Paul Finkleman |archivedate=January 5, 2013 }}</ref> He was twice a fellow of the [[Japan Society for the Promotion of Science]], resident at [[Nanzan University]] in Nagoya, Japan in 2001 and in 2011-12.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lists.ucla.edu/pipermail/conlawprof/2001-May/007323.html |accessdate=February 18, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012063112/http://lists.ucla.edu/pipermail/conlawprof/2001-May/007323.html|title=Lawprof claims that Indian-themed mascots are illegal |archivedate=October 12, 2013 }}</ref>
In 2012, Finkelman was the John Hope Franklin Visiting Professor of American Legal History at [[Duke Law School]]. In spring 2014, he was the Justice [[Pike Hall, Jr.]] Visiting Professor at the [[Paul M. Hebert Law Center]] of [[Louisiana State University]] in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]].Throughout 2014 and 2015, Finkelman was a Senior Fellow at the Penn Program on Democracy, Citizenship, and Constitutionalism at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] and a Scholar-in-Residence at the [[National Constitution Center]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://constitutioncenter.org/about/scholars-advisory-panel |title=National Constitution Center Scholars Advisory Panel |website=constitutioncenter.org |date= |accessdate=February 9, 2016}}</ref> In 2015, he was appointed the Ariel F. Sallows Visiting Professor of Human Rights Law at the [[University of Saskatchewan College of Law]]. In 2017 he was the John E. Murray Visiting Professor of Law at the [[University of Pittsburgh School of Law]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://law.pitt.edu/people/paul-finkelman|title=Paul Finkelman {{!}} PittLaw|website=law.pitt.edu|language=en|access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> In the Fall of 2017 he held a Fulbright Chair in Human Rights and Social Justice at the [[University of Ottawa]].
From 2003 to 2006, Finkelman was President of the 1921 Tulsa Race Riot Memorial Foundation. In 2009, he was elected a member of the American Antiquarian Society. Since 2003, he has been a board member of the Gilder Lehrman Center for the Study of Slavery, Abolition, and Resistance at Yale University. Since 2001, he has been the scholar/convener of the annual scholarly conference of the U.S. Capitol Historical Society.
==Expert witness and analyst== Called an "excellent legal historian",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.volokh.com/archives/archive_2006_07_23-2006_07_29.shtml#1153890852 |title=The Volokh Conspiracy |website=Volokh.com |date= |accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref> even by scholars who disagree with him, Finkelman was an expert witness against [[Alabama Supreme Court]] Chief Justice [[Roy Moore]] in ''[[Glassroth v. Moore]]'' (Al. 2002)(the "Ten Commandments" case), as well as an expert witness for the plaintiff in ''[[Popov v. Hayashi]]'' (S.F. Sup. Ct. CA, 2002) (determining who owned [[Barry Bonds]]'s 73rd home run ball). Professor Finkelman has also been part of ''amicus curie'' briefs for cases related to [[Guantanamo Bay detainment camp]], gay marriage in [[New York State]], [[affirmative action]], and [[separation of church and state]]. In 2013, he was the lead named amicus in briefs before the Supreme Court involving affirmative action (''[[Schuette v. Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action]]''<ref>{{cite web|title=Brief of Paul Finkelman and 75 Other Historians and Scholars as Amici Curiae in Support of Respondents|url=http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/publications/supreme_court_preview/briefs-v2/12-682_resp_amcu_pf-etal.authcheckdam.pdf|format=PDF|website=Americanbar.org|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref>) and prayer delivered at public meetings (''[[Town of Greece v. Galloway]]''<ref>{{cite web|title=Brief of Paul Finkelman, Steven K. Green, Michael I. Meyerson, John A. Ragosta, and 36 Other Legal Historians and Scholars of Religion and American Law as Amici Curiae in Support of Respondents |url=http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/publications/supreme_court_preview/briefs-v2/12-696_resp_amcu_pf-etal.authcheckdam.pdf|format=PDF|website=Americanbar.org|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref>). The U.S Supreme Court has cited Finkelman in four decisions.<ref>The Ten Commandments on the Courthouse Lawn and Elsewhere, 73 Fordham Law Review 1477-1520 (2005). Cited by the U.S. Supreme Court in Van Orden v. Perry (2005).</ref><ref>It Really Was About a Well Regulated Militia, 59 ''Syracuse Law Review'' 267-282 (2008). Cited by the U.S. Supreme Court in McDonald et al. v. City of Chicago (2010).</ref><ref>Defending Slavery: Proslavery Thought in the Old South. Boston, MA: Bedford/St. Martin's, 2003. Cited by the U.S. Supreme Court in Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin (2013).</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Brief of Paul Finkelman, Steven K. Green, Michael I. Meyerson, John A. Ragosta, and 36 Other Legal Historians and Scholars of Religion and American Law as Amici Curiae in Support of Respondents |url=http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/publications/supreme_court_preview/briefs-v2/12-696_resp_amcu_pf-etal.authcheckdam.pdf|format=PDF|website=Americanbar.org. Cited by U.S. Supreme Court in Town of Greece v. Galloway (2014)}}</ref>
In April 2007, Finkelman appeared at Harvard Law School for a retrial of the ''[[Dred Scott v. Sandford]]'' case.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.charleshamiltonhouston.org/Events/Event.aspx?id=100027 |title=Charles Hamilton Houston Institute for Race and Justice » 150th Anniversary of Dred Scott v. Sandford: Race, Citizenship & Justice |website=Charleshamiltonhouston.org |date= |accessdate=January 4, 2016 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He was an expert witness for Sandford.<ref>Was Dred Scott Correctly Decided? An "Expert Report" For the Defendant, 12, ''Lewis & Clark Law Review'' 1219–1252 (2008).</ref> Attorney [[Kenneth Starr]] was another expert witness before the mock court of federal justices; led by [[U.S. Supreme Court]] Justice [[Stephen Breyer]].
Finkelman has also appeared in several historical films, including [[Ken Burns]]'s [[Thomas Jefferson (documentary)|documentary on Thomas Jefferson]] (for which he was invited to the Clinton White House), and a documentary about the Barry Bonds' home run ball, ''[[Up for Grabs (2004 film)|Up for Grabs]]''. Television and radio programs which have used him as an analyst have been broadcast on [[NPR]], [[PBS]], [[CNN]], and [[ESPN]]. Finkelman has served on numerous editorial and advisory boards, as well as delivered more than 150 papers and lectures in the United States, and in Austria, Canada, China, Colombia (SA), France, Germany, Ireland (Eire), Israel, Italy, Japan, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom.
==Publications== Finkelman has published more than 50 books and hundreds of scholarly articles. His interests include [[slavery]], race, [[civil rights]], [[civil liberties]], the [[United States Constitution]] and [[United States constitutional law|constitutional law]], and baseball. Finkelman was listed as one of the ten most-cited legal historians in [[Brian Leiter]]'s survey of most-cited law professors by specialty from 2000 to 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leiterrankings.com/faculty/2007faculty_impact_areas.shtml |title=Brian Leiter Most Cited Law Professors by Specialty, 2000-2007 |website=Leiterrankings.com |date= |accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref>
Finkelman has also written numerous entries for encyclopedias and reference works. More than eighty short book reviews he has written have appeared in a wide variety of scholarly journals. His essays, op-eds and blogs have been published in the ''[[New York Times]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', ''[[USA Today]]'', ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]'', the ''[[Huffington Post]]'', [[theRoot.com]], and other non-scholarly avenues. Among them have been about [[Thomas Jefferson and slavery|Thomas Jefferson's relationship with slavery]]<ref>''[[The New York Times]]'', December 1, 2012, p. A25.</ref> and several concerning the American Civil War in the Disunion section of the ''New York Times''' The Opinionator blog.<ref>[http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/author/paul-finkelman/] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203224343/http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/author/paul-finkelman/ |date=December 3, 2013 }}</ref> While at the [[Binghamton University|SUNY Binghamton]], Finkelman edited the 18-volume ''Articles on American Slavery'', collecting nearly 400 important articles on slavery in the United States, which Garland Publishing published in 1989. Finkelman also edited ''The Political Lincoln: An Encyclopedia'' (2009), published by [[CQ Press]], and is an advisor to the [[Abraham Lincoln Bicentennial Commission]].<ref>[http://www.paulfinkelman.com/sub.php?id=2] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091010064231/http://www.paulfinkelman.com/sub.php?id=2 |date=October 10, 2009 }}</ref> He is the editor-in-chief of the book series, ''Routledge Historical Americans'', co-editor-in-chief of ''Studies in Southern Legal History'' at the University of Georgia Press, and co-editor of ''Law Politics and Society in the Midwest'' at Ohio University Press.
''Partial List of Publications'' * ''A Brief Narrative of the Cast and Tryal of John Peter Zenger''. Bedford/St. Martin's, 2010. * ''A History of Michigan Law''. Co-edited with Martin J. Hershock. Ohio University Press, 2006. * ''A March of Liberty: A Constitutional History of the United States''. With Melvin I. '''Postsecularism''' refers to a range of theories regarding the persistence or [[Growth of religion|resurgence of religious beliefs]] or practices in the present. The "post-" may refer to after the end of secularism or after the beginning of secularism.
== Use == The term “postsecular” has been used in sociology, political theory,<ref>Kyrlezhev, Aleksandr. “The Postsecular Age: Religion and Culture Today.” Trans. Joera Mulders and Philip Walters. Religion, State and Society 36.1 (2008): 21-31. Print.</ref><ref>McLennan, Gregor. “The Postsecular Turn.” Theory, Culture & Society 27.4 (2010): 3-20. Print.</ref> religious studies, art studies,<ref>King, Mike. “Art and the Postsecular.” Journal of Visual Art Practice 4.1 (2005): 3-17. Print.</ref> literary studies,<ref>Kaufmann, Michael. “Locating the Postsecular.” Religion & Literature 41.3 (2009): 67-73. Print.</ref><ref>Mohamed, Feisal G. Milton and the Post-Secular Present: Ethics, Politics, Terrorism. Stanford, CA: Stanford UP, 2011. Print.</ref> education<ref>{{Cite book|title=Educational Philosophy for a Post-secular Age|last=Lewin|first=David|publisher=Routledge|year=2016|isbn=9781138923669|location=London|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> and other fields. [[Jürgen Habermas]] is widely credited for popularizing the term,<ref>Habermas, Jürgen. "Secularism's Crisis of Faith: Notes on Post-Secular Society". ''New perspectives quarterly''. vol. 25 (2008) p. 17-29.</ref><ref>Reder, Michael and Josef Schmidt. “Habermas and Religion.” An Awareness of What Is Missing: Faith and Reason in a Post-Secular Age. Jürgen Habermas, et al. Trans. Ciaran Cronin. Cambridge, UK: Polity, 2010. 1-14. Print.</ref> to refer to current times in which the idea of modernity is perceived as failing and, at times, morally unsuccessful, so that, rather than a stratification or separation, a new peaceful dialogue and tolerant coexistence between the spheres of faith and reason<ref>The title of a very recent book of [[Jean-Marc-Ferry]] is ''La Raison et la foi''</ref> must be sought in order to learn mutually.<ref>Buston, Fernando del. 2014. ''[«El Estado debe proteger a la religión»]''. El Comercio. Date access: January 10, 2015: ''"Jürgen Habermas ha acuñado el término de postsecularidad. Se da por fallida la idea central de la modernidad de que la religión iba a desaparecer y se establece una nueva relación entre razón y religión. Habermas plantea que es necesario emprender un aprendizaje mutuo entre las sociedades modernas y las creencias, o entre razón secular y fe. Se inicia una nueva época de mutuas tolerancias. La razón no puede echar por la borda el potencial de sentido de las religiones y éstas deben traducir sus contenidos racionalmente."''</ref> In this sense, Habermas insists that both religious people and secularist people should not exclude each other, but to learn from one another and coexist tolerantly.<ref>[http://www.resetdoc.org/EN/Habermas-Istanbul.php A “post-secular” society – what does that mean?] by Jurgen Habermas June 2008.</ref><ref>Javier Espinosa. ''[http://www.uclm.es/actividades0304/seminarios/spinoza/pdf/cuadernos/22.pdf The religion in the public sphere. Habermas, Toland and Spinoza]''. Universidad de Castilla-La Mancha</ref> Massimo Rosati says that in a post secular society, religious and secular perspectives are on even ground, meaning that the two theoretically share equal importance. Modern societies that have considered themselves fully secular until recently have to change their value systems accordingly as to properly accommodate this co-existence.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Making of a Postsecular Society: A Durkheimian Approach to Memory, Pluralism and Religion in Turkey (Classical and Contemporary Social Theory)|last = Rosati|first = Massimo|publisher = Ashgate Publishing Company|year = 2015|isbn = 978-1472423122|location = |pages = 83}}</ref>
Charles Taylor’s ''[[A Secular Age]]'' is also frequently invoked as describing the postsecular,<ref>Smith, James K. A. “Secular Liturgies and the Prospects for a ‘Post-Secular’ Sociology of Religion.” The Post-Secular in Question: Religion in Contemporary Society. Ed. Philip S. Gorski, et al. New York, NY: New York UP 2012. 159-184. Print.</ref> though there is sometimes disagreement over what each author meant with the term. Particularly contested is the question of whether “postsecular” refers to a new sociological phenomenon or to a new awareness of an existing phenomenon—that is, whether society was secular and now is becoming post-secular or whether society was never and is not now becoming secular even though many people had thought it was or thought it was going to be.<ref>Jacobsen, Rhonda Hustedt, and Douglas G. Jacobsen. “Postsecular America: A New Context for Higher Education.” The American University in a Postsecular Age. Ed. Rhonda Hustedt Jacobsen and Douglas G. Jacobsen. Oxford: Oxford UP, 2008. 3-16. Print.</ref><ref>Hadden, Jeffrey K. “Toward Desacralizing Secularization Theory.” Social Forces 65.3 (1987): 587-611. Print.</ref> Some suggest that the term is so conflicted as to be of little use.<ref>Beckford, James A. “Public Religions and the Postsecular: Critical Reflections.” Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion. 51.1 (2012): 1-19. Print.</ref> Others suggest that the flexibility of the term is one of its strengths.<ref>Dunn, Allen. “The Precarious Integrity of the Postsecular.” Boundary 2: An International Journal of Literature and Culture 37.3 (2010): 91-99. Print.</ref>
In literary studies, the term has been used to indicate a sort of postmodern religious or spiritual sensibility in certain contemporary texts.<ref>McClure, John A.. Partial Faiths: Postsecular Fiction in the Age of Pynchon and Morrison. Athens, GA: U of Georgia P, 2007.</ref>

The '''Protecting Internet Freedom Act''' was introduced in June 2016 by United States [[Senator]] [[Ted Cruz]] in order to "prohibit the National Telecommunications and Information Administration from allowing the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority functions contract to lapse unless specifically authorized to do so by an Act of Congress."
==Background== United States government oversight of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers ([[ICANN]]) by the National Telecommunications and Information Administration ([[NTIA]]) was scheduled to end in October 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/15/technology/us-to-give-up-role-in-internet-domain-names.html|title=U.S. to Cede Its Oversight of Addresses on Internet|first=Edward|last=Wyatt|date=14 March 2014|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> A prior agreement had ensured that the United States government must be consulted on any "modifications, additions, or deletions" to the [[DNS root zone|root zone file]] which is maintained under subcontract by ICANN.<ref>http://www.ntia.doc.gov/files/ntia/publications/amend11_052206.pdf</ref>
On June 9, 2016, NTIA announced that ICANN's plan for replacing its oversight with a "multi-stakeholder model".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntia.doc.gov/press-release/2016/iana-stewardship-transition-proposal-meets-criteria-complete-privatization|title=NTIA Finds IANA Stewardship Transition Proposal Meets Criteria to Complete Privatization - National Telecommunications and Information Administration|website=www.ntia.doc.gov}}</ref> The California non-profit has a board of 20 members<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.icann.org/resources/pages/board-of-directors|title=Board of Directors - ICANN|website=www.icann.org}}</ref> and an advisory committee made up of representatives of 171 countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/17yVvuUIGcbTN5xfCfLbtpK36B-2Uc12m6EcaVQHOilk/edit?usp=sharing&usp=embed_facebook|title=091316 Members list GAC Sept 2016|website=Google Docs}}</ref> In order to make a recommendation to the board, all countries must agree unanimously. The board can then reject their recommendations.
The goal of the Protecting Internet Freedom Act is to disallow the transition to the multi-stakeholder model in favor of continued US government oversight. However, the NTIA argued that the opposite is true, and preventing privatization would in fact lead to "the United Nations...or another intergovernmental organization to take over stewardship of the DNS."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntia.doc.gov/other-publication/2016/q-and-iana-stewardship-transition-0|title=Q and A on IANA Stewardship Transition - National Telecommunications and Information Administration|website=www.ntia.doc.gov}}</ref>

{{no footnotes|date=August 2011}} {{distinguish|Restructuring}}
'''Reconstruction''' in [[law]] refers typically to the transfer of a company's (or several companies') business to a new company. The old company will get put into liquidation, and shareholders will agree to take shares of equivalent value in the new company.
In [[UK company law]], the governing provisions are in the [[Insolvency Act 1986]], ss. 110–111. The sanction of a court is not required (unlike under a so-called "[[scheme of arrangement]]", which could or creditors). Yet if a shareholder objects, he or she may require a cash payment instead of shares. Creditors who object to have their debts transferred to a new company can demand satisfactions during the old company's liquidation.
Small private companies, family companies and investment trusts often use the procedure. The purposes can vary, from changing the objects of the business, varying share class rights, or reorganize before a [[demerger]] takes place.
==See also== *[[Mergers and acquisitions]] *[[Bankruptcy]]
==References== *Len Sealy and [[Sarah Worthington]] (2007) ''Cases and Materials in Company law'', 8th Ed., Oxford University Press *Paul Davies (2008) ''Gower's Modern Company Law'', 8th Ed., Sweet and Maxwell
