See the Memorandum of the Master of the Rolls [in the the Court of the King's Bench] of the 8th August 1722, said [...] to have been determined by the Lords of the Privy Council, upon an appeal to the King in Council[,] from the foreign Plantations. https://books.google.com/books?id=SzlFAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA30&lpg=PA30&dq=august+1722+%22not+bind+them%22&source=bl&ots=wLP9ciH_gr&sig=sq9hUv7vRXU1HSOtZASV-04hf7E&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=august%201722%20%22not%20bind%20them%22&f=false https://play.google.com/books/reader?id=SzlFAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&output=reader&hl=en_GB&pg=GBS.PA30 https://books.google.com/books?id=C24DAAAAQAAJ&pg=PT83&dq=9+august+1722+%22not+bind+them%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjRgreQ5NTRAhWIWBoKHVQBCXwQ6AEIHTAA#v=onepage&q=9%20august%201722%20%22not%20bind%20them%22&f=false https://play.google.com/books/reader?id=C24DAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover&output=reader&hl=en_GB&pg=GBS.PT83 And even that particularly Jersey law or legislation (Law) in essentially legally purely ceremonial and otherwise have no legal effect. --><!--DO NOT RESTORE TEXT. The act extends to the whole United Kingdom. It has no provision on extent, but by necessary implication it extends to the [[Crown dependencies]] and [[British Overseas Territories]], following the precedent of other Acts affecting the Sovereign such as the [[Accession Declaration Act 1910]] and the [[Regency Acts]] of 1937, 1943 and 1953.<ref name = "Bill-EN">{{Citation|date=2012-12-13|title=Succession to the Crown Bill--Explanatory Notes.|author=The Cabinet Office|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/bills/cbill/2012-2013/0110/en/130110en.htm|accessdate=2014-04-07|at=para. 14|quote= The Bill has no provision on extent but it will extend to the Crown Dependencies and British Overseas Territories by necessary implication. This follows the precedent of other Acts affecting the Sovereign, such as the Accession Declaration Act 1910 and the Regency Acts of 1937, 1943 and 1953.}}</ref> However, [[Jersey]] passed its own Succession to the Crown (Jersey) Law 2013 to give effect to the provisions in Jersey law.<ref>{{cite act |title= Succession to the Crown (Jersey) Law 2013|type= Act|number= 14|date= 2013|url= http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/Display.aspx?url=%2flaw%2flawsinforce%2fhtm%2fLawFiles%2f2013%2fL-14-2013.pdf}}</ref> -->
==External reference== The legislation passed in the realms of Australia, Barbados, and Canada make reference to the United Kingdom legislation in different ways. The [[Succession to the Crown Act 2015]], passed by the parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, is expressed to be for changing "the law relating to the effect of gender and marriage on royal succession, consistently with changes made to that law in the United Kingdom, so that the Sovereign of Australia is the same person as the Sovereign of the United Kingdom". The [[Succession to the Throne Act, 2013]], passed by the parliament of Canada, refers to the bill (not the act): "The alteration in the law touching the Succession to the Throne set out in the bill laid before the Parliament of the United Kingdom and entitled A Bill to Make succession to the Crown not depend on gender; to make provision about Royal Marriages; and for connected purposes is assented to." The parliament of Barbados' Succession to the Throne Act, 2013, uses similar wording to Canada's law: "The Parliament of Barbados acquiesces to the alteration in the law relating to the Succession to the Throne set out in the Bill laid before the Parliament of the United Kingdom and entitled A Bill to make succession to the Crown not depend on gender; to make provision about Royal Marriages; and for connected purposes."<ref>{{citation| url= http://www.barbadosparliament.com/htmlarea/uploaded/File/Bills/2013/Succession%20to%20the%20Throne%20Act,%202013.pdf| author=Elizabeth II| title=An Act to provide for the Parliament of Barbados to acquiesce to alterations in the law relating to the succession to the Throne of the United Kingdom| date=2013| publisher=Government Information Service| location=Bridgetown| accessdate=31 March 2015}}</ref>
==Commentary==
===Royal family=== On 6 January 2013, the ''Daily Mail'' reported that the Prince of Wales had "serious concerns" about the proposed legislation:
{{quote|[I]n a meeting with Richard Heaton, permanent secretary at the Cabinet Office, the Prince is said to have raised concerns about what will happen if his grandchild is allowed to marry a Roman Catholic (under [[Canon law (Catholic Church)|canon law]] 1125 of the Catholic Church)<ref>{{citation| url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/the-duchess-of-cambridge-and-the-right-royal-baby-battle-8445750.html| title=The Duchess of Cambridge and the right royal baby battle| date=10 January 2013| newspaper=London Evening Standard| accessdate=14 January 2013}}</ref>... [and] the potential impact of changing the rules of Royal succession for other titles that are currently passed down the male line.<ref name="dailymailcharles">{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2258172/Prince-Charles-Shake-let-daughter-succeed-throne-thought-through.html |title=My fears on rushed new laws over Kate's baby, by Charles: Shake-up to let a daughter succeed to the throne 'has not been thought through', says Prince |work=Daily Mail |date=6 January 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2013}}</ref>}}
A spokesman for the Cabinet Office and a spokesman for the Prince declined to comment on the ''Daily Mail'' report.<ref name="dailymailcharles"/> On 9 January 2013, Prime Minister David Cameron said in regard to the proposals that "there has been very thorough contact between No. 10 Downing Street and the palace, and all the issues are settled and agreed".<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= United Kingdom| url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmhansrd/cm130109/debtext/130109-0001.htm#13010946000010 | house= House of Commons| date= 9 January 2013| column= 310|title=Prime Minister}}</ref>
===Church of England=== On 21 January 2013, the Church of England published a briefing endorsing the bill's provisions and stating, "The use of fast-tracking procedures [for the bill] is acceptable."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.churchofengland.org/our-views/the-church-in-parliament/briefing-bills/succession-to-the-crown-bill.aspx |title=Church of England Briefing – Succession to the Crown Bill}}</ref> The same day, the ''Telegraph'' reported that the Church of England had written to MPs to express its official backing for the proposed changes.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/theroyalfamily/9816620/Nick-Clegg-urges-equal-rights-for-royal-girls-as-MPs-prepare-to-debate-rules-of-succession.html |title=Nick Clegg urges 'equal rights' for royal girls as MPs prepare to debate rules of succession |publisher=The Telegraph |date=21 January 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2013}}</ref>
===House of Commons=== A report on the rules of royal succession was prepared by the [[Political and Constitutional Reform Select Committee]] of the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]], chaired by [[Graham Allen (politician)|Graham Allen]], and was published in December 2011. The report welcomed the proposals, but drew attention to "connected issues that may be raised when the proposals are debated, depending on the scope of the bill, especially the future role of the Crown in the Church of England, and the continued ineligibility of women to succeed to the majority of [[hereditary peerage]]s, which remains a matter of public interest for as long as it has an impact on gender balance in the House of Lords".<ref>[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201012/cmselect/cmpolcon/1615/1615.pdf House of Commons Political and Constitutional Reform Committee, ''Rules of Royal Succession: Eleventh Report of Session 2010–12'', 7 December 2011]. Retrieved 3 December 2012</ref>
On 9 September 2012, the British government published a response to the report, reiterating that it intended to implement the [[Perth Agreement]] but had no plans to change the laws of succession to peerages or the established status of the Church of England.<ref>''Rules of Royal Succession: Government Response to the Committee's Eleventh Report of Session 2010–12''. Mark Harper MP, Minister for Political and Constitutional Reform, 10 September 2012.</ref>
===House of Lords=== On 21 January 2013, the House of Lords Constitution Committee published a report opposing the Government's plan to fast-track the bill, citing the legislation's "constitutional significance" and "possible unintended consequences".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201213/ldselect/ldconst/106/10603.htm |title=11th Report: The Succession to the Crown Bill |author=Constitution Committee |publisher=House of Lords}}</ref>
In response, the Government expanded the time allocated for the bill's debate in the House of Commons from one day to two days,<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= United Kingdom| url= https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmhansrd/cm130122/debtext/130122-0002.htm#13012253000001| house= House of Commons| date= 22 January 2013| column= 201|title=Succession to the Crown Bill}}</ref> and it decided not to fast-track the bill in the House of Lords, where the normal time limits were observed.<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= United Kingdom| url= https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201213/ldhansrd/text/130214-0002.htm| house= House of Lords| date= 14 February 2013| column= 829|title=Succession to the Crown Bill}}</ref>
==Bill stages== The first reading (introduction) of the bill in the House of Commons took place on 13 December 2012.<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= United Kingdom| url= https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmhansrd/cm121213/debtext/121213-0002.htm#12121342000015| house= House of Commons| date= 13 December 2012| column= 471|title=Bill Presented}}</ref> Passage of an Allocation of Time motion, the second reading, and the committee stage (in the form of a Committee of the Whole House) took place on 22 January 2013.<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= United Kingdom| url= https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmhansrd/cm130122/debtext/130122-0001.htm#13012239000002| house= House of Commons| date= 22 January 2013| column= 186|title=Succession to the Crown Bill (Allocation of Time)}}</ref> The report stage and third reading (passage) took place on 28 January 2013.<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= United Kingdom| url= https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmhansrd/cm130128/debtext/130128-0002.htm#13012834000001| house= House of Commons| date= 28 January 2013| column= 695|title=Succession to the Crown Bill}}</ref> The only amendment made in the House of Commons was to insert the words "from the marriage" after the word "descendants" in section 3(3), which was passed without debate.<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= United Kingdom| url= https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201213/cmhansrd/cm130122/debtext/130122-0004.htm| house= House of Commons| date= 22 January 2013| column= 273|speaker= [[Chloe Smith]] MP|position= Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet Office)|title=Succession to the Crown Bill}}</ref>
The first reading of the bill in the House of Lords took place on 29 January 2013.<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= United Kingdom| url= https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201213/ldhansrd/text/130129-0001.htm#13012966000411| house= House of Lords| date= 29 January 2013| column= 1439|title=Succession to the Crown Bill: First Reading}}</ref> The bill passed second reading on 14 February 2013 and was reviewed by committee on 28 February 2013. The report stage was on 13 March 2013.<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= United Kingdom| url= https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201213/ldhansrd/text/130313-0001.htm#13031351000661|title=Succession to the Crown Bill: Report| house= House of Lords | date= 13 March 2013| column= 267|speaker= |position=}}</ref> The bill was passed at the third reading on 22 April.<ref>{{cite hansard |jurisdiction= United Kingdom| url= https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201213/ldhansrd/text/130422-0001.htm#1304224000390| house= House of Lords| date= 22 April 2013| column= 1216|speaker= |position=|title=Succession to the Crown Bill: Third Reading}}</ref> No amendments were made to the bill in the House of Lords, and it received the Royal Assent on 25 April 2013.<ref name="UK Parliament website"/>
== Consents for marriages under the Act == Consents for marriages under the Act appear in the Privy Council Orders. The first person in line of succession to receive consent under the new law is [[Prince Harry]]. {| class="wikitable" !Date !Applicant !Spouse !Privy Council Orders |- |14 March 2018 |[[Prince Henry of Wales]] |[[Meghan Markle]] |<span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&rft.genre=unknown&rft.btitle=No.+13347&rft.pages=541&rft.date=1791-09-27&rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thegazette.co.uk%2FLondon%2Fissue%2F13347%2Fpage%2F541&rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARoyal+Marriages+Act+1772" class="Z3988"></span>[http://privycouncil.independent.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/2018-03-14-List-of-Business-Part-1.pdf Privy Council Orders for 14 March 2018] |}
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em|group=note}}
==See also== *[[Monarchy of the United Kingdom]] *[[Royal Succession Act 2013]], New Zealand legislation to implement the Perth Agreement. * [[Equality (Titles) Bill]], related UK legislation pertaining to the succession of female heirs to hereditary titles and peerages * {{Wikipedia books link|Perth Agreement 2011 and other articles, linked directly or indirectly}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2013/20/enacted Full text of the Act] * [https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/bills/cbill/2012-2013/0110/cbill_2012-20130110_en_2.htm Full text of the bill as introduced to the House of Commons] * [http://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/RP12-81/RP12-81.pdf Research paper by the House of Commons Library]

revision.text: {{italic title}} {{Nihongo|'''''Takahashi Ujibumi'''''|高橋氏文|}} is a historical clan record of the Takahashi clan. It served as an appeal for court arbitration between two fighting clans. The author(s) is unknown, but the contents suggest that it was composed prior to 789. The text only survives today in fragments quoted in other texts such as {{Nihongo|''Honchō Gatsuryō''|本朝月令||extra=c. 930-946}}, {{Nihongo|''Seiji Yōryaku''|政事要略||extra=1002}}, and {{Nihongo|''Nenjū Gyōji Hishō''|年中行事秘抄||}}. Both the Takahashi and Azumi clans served in the [[Royal Table Office]]. Conflict between the two clans erupted with many conflicts occurring after 716. Seeking arbitration and a resolution to the conflict, both clans submitted their clan records to the imperial court. This is the Takahashi record; the Azumi clan record is unknown. ==Contents== Pieced together, the text consists of three major sections: *Takahashi clan ancestor Iwakamutsukari no Mikoto served [[Emperor Keikō]] meals and received the title "Kashiwade" (chief). *The imperial proclamation after Iwakamutsukari died. *A record of the 792 arbitration by the [[Daijō-kan|Department of State]] regarding the conflicts between the two clans. ==Value== The text is highly valued as the oldest existing clan record. In addition, the ''[[Nihon Shoki]]'' (720) makes reference to the Kashiwade clan,Sakamoto, Tarō ''et al.'' (1965). ''Nihon Koten Bungaku Taikei: Nihon Shoki,'' p. 510. a title bestowed up the Takahashi clan. This suggests the possibility that the Takahashi clan record, at least in part, was used as a reference in compiling ''Nihon Shoki'' while also suggesting that parts of it may be even older. Linguistically, the text includes a number of passages utilizing the archaic [[Jōdai Tokushu Kanazukai]] spellings. However, there are some inconsistencies which indicate that parts of it date to a late 8th century. ==See also== * [[Historiography of Japan]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{NKBJ}} * {{NKBD}} * {{cite book | last = Okimori | first = Takuya |author2=Satō Makoto |author3=Yajima Izumi | title = Kodai Ujibumi-shū: Sumiyoshi Taisha Jindaiki, Kogo Shūi, Shinsen Kisōki, Takahashi Ujibumi, Hata-shi Honkeichō | publisher = Yamakawa Shuppansha | year = 2012 | isbn = 978-4-634-59394-7 }} * {{cite book | last = Omodaka | first = Hisataka | authorlink = | title = Jidaibetsu Kokugo Daijiten: Jōdaihen | publisher = [[Sanseido|Sanseidō]] | year = 1967 | location = | pages = | url = | language = Japanese | doi = | isbn = 4-385-13237-2 }} * {{cite book | last = Sakamoto | first = Tarō | authorlink = |author2=Ienaga Saburō |author3=Inoue Mitsusada |author4=[[Ōno Susumu]] | title = Nihon Koten Bungaku Taikei: Nihon Shoki (vol. 2) | publisher = [[Iwanami Shoten Publishing|Iwanami Shoten]] | year = 1965 | location = | pages = | url = | doi = | isbn = 4-00-060068-0 }} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110822102827/http://mononobe.digiweb.jp/siryou/takahashi.html ''Takahashi Ujibumi''], online edition [[Category:Nara period]] [[Category:8th-century history books]] [[Category:Old Japanese texts]] [[Category:Arbitration]] [[Category:8th-century books|T]]

The discovery of [[tetracycline]] engendered an enormous amount of litigation. In late 1958, the U.S. government charged [[Pfizer]] and [[American Cyanamid]] with price fixing in connection with tetracycline. <ref> “Government: Dissent on the Wonder Drugs,” Aug. 11, 1958, http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,825466,00.html and Pub Policy: Pricing Fixing.</ref> That and other related litigation lasted until 1982. Often, the series of cases is referred to as the “antibiotics litigation.”
==Background==
The focal point of the case was the two companies’ settlement of an interference proceeding before the PTO (the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office) over the priority of their respective applications for tetracycline. Under the settlement, American Cyanamid, which had acquired Heyden Chemicals‘s pending tetracycline application, conceded the priority of Pfizer’s application, withdrew its own application and exchanged cross licenses with Pfizer. According to the indictment of American Cyanamid, Bristol Myers, Pfizer, and Cyanamid knew that tetracycline represented a threat to the continuation of their dominant positions and unreasonably high profits. To keep that threat in check, the indictment alleges, Cyanamid bought out Heyden's rights to the development and agreed to help Pfizer get the tetracycline patent. In return, charges the Justice Department. Pfizer licensed Cyanamid to produce the drug. Later, to avoid a court fight that might have nullified the patent, Pfizer and Cyanamid let Bristol-Myers in. <ref> “Public Policy: Antitrust and & Antibiotics, August 25, 1961. http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,895666,00.html</ref>
The Federal Trade Commission found that the cross-license, combined with the fact that Pfizer had withheld information that it knew or should have known was relevant to the patentability of tetracycline, constituted an attempt by Pfizer and American Cyanamid to share in an unlawful monopoly. <ref> Cacciapaglia and Rockman, “Proposed Drug Industry Antitrust Act--Patents, Pricing, and the Public “ 30 Geo. Wash. L. Rev. 875, 894 (1961-1962); Kennedy, “Patent and Antitrust Policy--Acquisition of Patents by Fraud or by Unfair or Deceptive Acts or Practices,” 35 George Washington Law Review 512, 531 (1966-1967) For an early discussion, see Costello, “The Tetracycline Conspiracy: Structure, Conduct and Performance in the Drug Industry,” Antitrust L. & Economic Rev. 12 (1967-1968)</ref> Ultimately, the government lost. <ref> State of North Carolina v. Chas Pfizer & Co Inc. 537 F. 2d 67 (4th Cir. 1976).</ref>
The government also sought to cancel the Pfizer patent on tetracycline, alleging fraud and the concealment of information that would have been relevant to the patent examiner. The government lost the final appeal of that case in 1982. <ref> U.S. v. Pfizer,, 676 F.2d 51 (1982). </ref>
== See also == * [[Price fixing cases]]

{{refimprove|date=January 2013}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''The House I Live In'' (2012 film)}} {{Infobox film | name = The House I Live In | image = TheHouseILiveIn poster.jpg | caption = | director = [[Eugene Jarecki]] | producer = Eugene Jarecki
Melinda Shopsin | writer = Eugene Jarecki | narrator = | starring = [[Nannie Jeter]]
[[David Simon]] | music = Robert Miller | cinematography = Sam Cullman
Derek Hallquist | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2012|10|05}} | runtime = 108 minutes | country = United States
International{{cite web |url=http://www.landmarktheatres.com/Films/films_frameset.asp?id=117492 |title=The House I Live In at Landmark Theatres |accessdate=November 18, 2012 |work=Landmark Theatres }} | language = English | budget = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The House I Live In''''', directed by [[Eugene Jarecki]], is a 2012 [[documentary film]] about the [[War on Drugs]] in the [[United States]]. ==Participants== *[[Michelle Alexander]] (civil rights litigator and the author of 2010's ''The New Jim Crow'') *Shanequa Benitez (resident of Cromwell Towers housing project in [[Yonkers, New York]]) *The Honorable [[Mark W. Bennett]] (U.S. District Court Judge in [[Sioux City, Iowa]]) *[[Charles Bowden]] (journalist covering drug war-caused violence on the [[Mexico-United States border|Mexico-U.S. border]]) *Mike Carpenter (Chief of Security at Joseph Harp Correctional Center in [[Lexington, Oklahoma]]) {{cite web |last1=Coppernoll |first1=Carrie |title=Weapons surface in prison sweep |url=https://newsok.com/article/2904111/weapons-surface-in-prison-sweep |website=newsok.com |publisher=newsok |accessdate=5 June 2018}} *Marshal Larry Cearley (Police Officer in the village of [[Magdalena, New Mexico]]) *Eric Franklin (Warden of the Lexington Corrections Center in Lexington, Oklahoma) *Maurice Haltiwanger (sentenced to 20 years for crack cocaine distribution) *[[Carl Hart|Dr. Carl Hart]]{{cite web|url=http://surc.columbia.edu/hart.htm |title=Substance Use Research Center |publisher=Surc.columbia.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-06-05 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130623023951/http://surc.columbia.edu/hart.htm |archivedate=2013-06-23 }} (Professor of Clinical Neuroscience, [[Columbia University]]) *Nannie Jeter (resident of [[New Haven, Connecticut]]) *Anthony Johnson (former small-time drug dealer in Yonkers, New York) *Dr. [[Gabor Maté (physician)|Gabor Maté]] (Hungarian-born physician specializing in the treatment of addiction - has been working in [[Vancouver, British Columbia]], Canada for several decades) *Mark Mauer{{cite web|url=http://www.sentencingproject.org/detail/person.cfm?person_id=3 |title=Marc Mauer |publisher=[[The Sentencing Project]] |date= |accessdate=2013-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130225014111/http://www.sentencingproject.org/detail/person.cfm?person_id=3 |archivedate=2013-02-25 }} (Director, [[The Sentencing Project]]) *Richard Lawrence Miller{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Richard-Lawrence-Miller/e/B001HCW7YM/ref=ntt_dp_epwbk_0 |title=Richard Lawrence Miller: Books, Biography, Blog, Audiobooks, Kindle |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2013-06-05 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305073322/http://www.amazon.com/Richard-Lawrence-Miller/e/B001HCW7YM/ref%3Dntt_dp_epwbk_0 |archivedate=2016-03-05 }} (American historian and expert on the history of U.S. drug laws) *[[Charles Ogletree]] (Jesse Climenko Professor of Law at Harvard Law School, and a former academic advisor to Barack and Michelle Obama) *Kevin Ott (serving life without parole on drug charges, Lexington Correctional Center, Lexington, Oklahoma) *Susan Randall{{cite web | url = http://www.vtprivateye.com/susan-randall-hansen-%E2%80%93-founder-director | title = Susan Randall – Founder & Director | accessdate = 2013-06-05 | publisher = VTPrivateeye.com | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120204050452/http://www.vtprivateye.com/susan-randall-hansen-%E2%80%93-founder-director | archivedate = 2012-02-04}} (Private investigator in [[Vermont]] - formerly a journalist/producer for National Public Radio, All Things Considered, Morning Edition, Vermont Public Radio, and a researcher and associate producer for the A&E series Biography) *[[David Simon]] (creator of ''[[The Wire]]'' on HBO) *Julie Stewart (President and founder of [[Families Against Mandatory Minimums]] aka FAMM) *Dennis Whidbee (former drug dealer, and the father of Anthony Johnson) *Officer Fabio Zuena (Police Officer in the city of [[Providence, Rhode Island]]) *[[David M. Kennedy (criminologist)|David Kennedy]] (Professor of Criminal Justice, [[John Jay College of Criminal Justice]] in New York City) ==Reception== The documentary has been well received. Among the [[review aggregator]]s, [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gave it 95% based on 55 reviews{{Rotten Tomatoes|the_house_i_live_in|The House I Live In}} and [[Metacritic]] gave it 77/100 based on 24 reviews.{{metacritic film|the-house-i-live-in|The House I Live In}} [[Roger Ebert]] says ''The House I Live In'' "makes a shattering case against the War on Drugs."{{cite news|first=Roger |last=Ebert |authorlink=Roger Ebert |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20121010/REVIEWS/121019998 |title=The House I Live In :: roberbert.com :: Reviews |work=[[Sun Times]] |date=October 10, 2012 |accessdate=January 14, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015002853/http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20121010%2FREVIEWS%2F121019998 |archivedate=October 15, 2012 }} {{rating|3.5|4}} [[Peter Bradshaw]] reviewed the film for ''[[The Guardian]]'' and summed it up as an "angry and personal attack on America's war on drugs [that] contends it is a grotesquely wasteful public-works scheme".{{cite news|first=Peter |last=Bradshaw |authorlink=Peter Bradshaw |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/nov/22/the-house-i-live-in-review |title=The House I Live In – review |work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |date=November 22, 2012 |accessdate=January 14, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110034221/http://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/nov/22/the-house-i-live-in-review |archivedate=November 10, 2013 }} {{rating|4|5}} ==Awards== * January 2012: Won the [[List of Sundance Film Festival award winners#2012|Grand Jury Prize: Documentary]] at the [[Sundance Film Festival]]. * April 2014: Won a [[Peabody Award]].{{cite web|url=http://www.peabodyawards.com/award-profile/independent-lens-the-house-i-live-in-pbs |title=Independent Lens: The House I Live In (PBS) |author= |date= |website=peabodyawards.com |publisher=[[Peabody Award]] |access-date=August 20, 2016 |quote= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160917230546/http://www.peabodyawards.com/award-profile/independent-lens-the-house-i-live-in-pbs |archivedate=September 17, 2016 }} ==See also== * [[List of page.title: Valuation using the Market Penetration Model

revision.comment: Bot: [[User:KolbertBot|HTTP→HTTPS]]
revision.text:
'''Valuation using the Market Penetration Model''' ('''MPM''') or the growth potential of a company<ref name="amazon">{{cite book | last = Hughes | first = David | authorlink = | title = The Business Value Myth | publisher = Canopy Law Books | series = | year = 2012 | doi = | url = https://www.amazon.co.uk/The-Business-Value-Myth-ebook/dp/B009XB91CU | asin = B009XB91CU }} </ref> is a method of estimating the value of a company by calculating the depth of its [[market penetration]] as evidenced by its [[customer base]] and industry niche.
The process consists of:
* profiling a company's type of customer and analysing which complementary companies share these customers.<ref>How to sell your business for maximum value: Part 1 http://www.canopylaw.com/about.php?pg=12</ref> * valuing the barriers to entry into the industry niche that the company operates in.
== Valuation overview ==
The Market Penetration Model focuses on the synergy and opportunities for fast growth between the target company and the acquiring company. It prioritises ability to exploit future customer opportunities over previous financial performance.<ref name="amazon" />
Many of the [[web 2.0]] start up successes are valued using this method, due to the perceived value of customer attention over past profit.<ref>How the sale of Instagram shows that the value of a business is not based on profit http://www.canopylaw.com/about.php?pg=2</ref>
== Advantages/disadvantages ==
=== Advantages ===
MPM has some advantages over other valuation methods:
* Values intangible factors: such as customer attention, which are not otherwise reflected in financial data. * Modern: MPM is relevant to web based businesses whose value is not accurately portrayed in financial figures and hard assets.
=== Disadvantages ===
The main criticisms can be summarised as:
* Intangible: the assessment of the value of particular customer segmentation and industry niches is highly subjective. * Reliance on competition between buyers: a buyer will not need to pay a premium for future growth potential if there is no competitive bidding process.
== Examples ==
[[Facebook]]'s purchase of [[Instagram]] was based on MPM.<ref name="ABC">{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/technology/2012/04/facebook-buys-instagram-for-1-billion/ |title=Facebook Buys Instagram for $1 Billion |work=[[ABC News]] |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=April 9, 2012 |accessdate=April 27, 2012 |first=Joanna |last=Stern}}</ref> [[Instagram]] was a relatively small company, employing 13 programmers and was just two years old at the time of the sale. It had no revenue, but was initially valued at $1 billion on account of it highly desirable customer base ([[social media]] fanatics, [[smart phone]] users) and its attractive industry niche (smart phone space).
Several other high-profile tech companies have had a valuation based on MPM including: [[Google]]'s purchase of Snapseed<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2012/9/17/3346182/google-acquires-snapseed-nik-software|title=Google takes on Instagram and Facebook by acquiring top iOS photo app Snapseed|publisher=The Verge|accessdate=September 17, 2012}}</ref> and Money Supermarket's purchase of MoneySavingExpert.com<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.moneysavingexpert.com/news/site/2012/06/moneysavingexpertcom-to-join-the-moneysupermarketcom-group|title=MoneySavingExpert.com to join the MoneySupermarket.com group|publisher=MoneySavingExpert.com|accessdate=June 1, 2012}}</ref> ($120million).
==References== {{Reflist}}

[[File:Attentatet i Stockholm 2017-8.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.5|The [[2017 Stockholm attack|2017 Stockholm truck ramming attack]] killed five.]] [[File:Jerusalem Bulldozer rampage 03.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.5|The [[2008 Jerusalem bulldozer attack]], killed three.]] {{Homicide}} A '''vehicle-ramming attack''' is a form of [[mass murder]] in which a perpetrator deliberately [[Ramming|rams]] a [[motor vehicle]] into a building, crowd of people,<ref name="ufouo">{{cite web|last1=Issued 13 December 2012|title=Department of Homeland Security-FBI Warning: Terrorist Use of Vehicle Ramming Tactics|url=https://publicintelligence.net/ufouo-dhs-fbi-warning-terrorist-use-of-vehicle-ramming-tactics/|publisher=FBI and Department of Homeland Security|accessdate=6 November 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141028004254/http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2014/07/140721-gaza-strip-tunnels-israel-hamas-palestinians/|archivedate=28 October 2014|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Rapoport2006">{{cite book|author=David C. Rapoport|title=Terrorism: The fourth or religious wave|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E1_SxOuUHmIC&pg=PA150|year=2006|publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]]|isbn=978-0-415-31654-5|pages=150–|archivedate=10 December 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141210203752/https://books.google.com/books?id=E1_SxOuUHmIC&pg=PA150|df=dmy-all}}</ref> or another vehicle. The earliest known use of a vehicle-ramming attack took place in 1973 in [[Prague]], former [[Czechoslovakia]], when [[Olga Hepnarová]] killed 8 people. According to [[Stratfor]] Global Intelligence analysts, this attack represented a new militant tactic which is less lethal but could prove more difficult to prevent than [[suicide bombings]].<ref name="stratfor"/>
Deliberate vehicle-ramming into crowd of people is a tactic used by [[terrorism|terrorists]],<ref name="nolorare">{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/crime/index.ssf/2017/02/mass_casualty_traffic_incident.html|title=Mass casualty traffic incidents like Endymion's are rare, but do happen|publisher=New Orleans Times-Picayune|accessdate=14 March 2016|date=February 27, 2017}}</ref> becoming a major terrorist tactic in the 2010s because it requires little skill to perpetrate and has the potential to cause significant casualties.<ref>Amanda Erickson & Isaac Stanley-Becker, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/03/22/as-the-london-attacks-show-the-sedate-sedan-can-be-turned-into-a-deadly-unpredictable-weapon/ How ramming cars into crowds became a major terror tactic], ''Washington Post'' (March 22, 2017).</ref><ref name="KeatingWeapons">{{cite news|last1=Keating|first1=Joshua|title=Why Terrorists Use Vehicles as Weapons|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_world_/2014/11/05/car_attack_in_jerusalem_why_are_terrorists_ramming_vehicles_into_crowds.html|accessdate=27 September 2017|publisher=Slate|date=5 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="JamisonThreat">{{cite news|last1=Jamison|first1=Alastair|title=Truck Attacks: Low-Tech, Soft Target Terrorism Is Growing Threat|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/berlin-truck-attack/truck-attacks-low-tech-soft-target-terrorism-growing-threat-n609996|accessdate=27 September 2017|publisher=NBC News|date=20 December 2016}}</ref> Deliberate vehicle-ramming has also been carried out in the course of other types of [[crime]]s,<ref>David Ormerod, John Cyril Smith & Brian Hogan, ''Smith and Hogan's Criminal Law'' (13th ed. 2011: Oxford University Press), p. 1138: "There are at least six ways that a person might be held liable for causing a death by driving. At the most extreme it is possible for D[efendant] to be liable for murder, as when he drivers at V[ictim] with intent to kill or do gbh ([[great bodily harm]])."</ref> including [[road rage]] incidents.<ref>R.G. Smart, "Transport Related Stress" in ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=E20HsuKHxaEC&pg=PA708#v=onepage&q&f=false Stress Consequences: Mental, Neuropsychological and Socioeconomic]'' (ed. George Fink: [[Academic Press]], 2009), p. 708: "A national study in the United States found that ... of respondents ... 1-2% had gotten out of their cars to hurt other drivers, deliberately hit other drivers, or had carried a weapon."</ref><ref>[http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/audi-driver-pleads-guilty-after-video-shows-him-mowing-down-man-in-road-rage-incident-in-new-brunswick Audi driver pleads guilty after video shows him mowing down man in road-rage incident in New Brunswick], Canadian Press (February 28, 2017).</ref> Deliberate vehicle-ramming incidents have also sometimes been ascribed to the driver's [[psychiatric disorder]].<ref name="Felthouse">Alan R. Felthouse, "[https://books.google.com/books?id=q_1q-ydoBWEC&pg=PA552 Personal Violence]" in ''The American Psychiatric Publishing Textbook of Forensic Psychiatry'' (2d ed.: eds. Robert I. Simon & Liza H. Gold), pp. 551-52: "An automobile is a potentially lethal machine. Litigation involving psychiatrists has resulted when a hospitalized patient, after discharges, caused a two-person vehicle accident with death or injuries to one or more victims ... Such cases involve three different types of scenarios. One is the vehicular crash that results from the patient's medication-induced drowsiness at the wheel ... The second scenario is a true accident but is unrelated to any prescribed medication. Rather, the patient's driving is impaired by the disabling effects of mental illness [or] recent consumption of nonprescribed drugs or alcohol. The third situation is when the patient deliberately crashes into another vehicle. Neuropsychiatric conditions that can be associated with an increased risk of vehicular crash include psychotic exacerbation of schizophrenia, profound or suicidal depression, dementia, and disturbances in consciousness, such as epilepsy and narcolepsy."</ref>{{Efn|Accidental vehicle ramming causing multiple deaths or injuries to pedestrians or others also occurs, although rarely.<ref name="nolorare"/> Causes of such accidental mass-casualty vehicular ramming include [[drunk driving|drunk]] and [[drug–impaired driving]] or driver error by elderly drivers.<ref name="Felthouse"/> See also [[sudden unintended acceleration]].<ref name="nolorare"/>}}
Vehicles have also been used by attackers to breach buildings with locked gates, before detonating explosives, as in the [[Saint-Quentin-Fallavier attack]].
==Causes propelling the rise of the tactic== According to the American [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]], the tactic has gained popularity because "Vehicle ramming offers terrorists with limited access to explosives or weapons an opportunity to conduct a homeland attack with minimal prior training or experience."<ref name=ufouo/> Counterterrorism researcher [[Daveed Gartenstein-Ross]] of the [[Foundation for the Defense of Democracies]] told ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' that the tactic has been on the rise in [[Israel]] because, "[[Israeli West Bank barrier|the security barrier]] is fairly effective, which makes it hard to get bombs into the country."<ref name="slate1">{{cite news|last1=Keating|first1=Joshua|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_world_/2014/11/05/car_attack_in_jerusalem_why_are_terrorists_ramming_vehicles_into_crowds.html|accessdate=6 November 2014|publisher=Slate|date=5 November 2014|title=Why Terrorists Use Vehicles as Weapons|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141106024619/http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_world_/2014/11/05/car_attack_in_jerusalem_why_are_terrorists_ramming_vehicles_into_crowds.html|deadurl=no|archivedate=6 November 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 2010, ''[[Inspire (magazine)|Inspire]]'', the online, English-language magazine produced by [[al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] urged mujahideen to choose "pedestrian only" locations and make sure to gain speed before ramming their vehicles into the crowd in order to "achieve maximum carnage".<ref name="slate1"/>
Vehicle attacks can be carried out by [[Lone wolf (terrorism)|lone-wolf terrorists]] who are inspired by an ideology, but who are not actually working within a specific political movement or group.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Daly|first1=Brian|title=Lone wolf terrorists hard to stop|url=http://www.edmontonsun.com/2014/10/21/soldier-dead-after-radicalized-quebec-man-ran-him-down-with-a-car|accessdate=6 November 2014|agency=[[Québecor Média|QMI]]|publisher=Edmonton Sun|date=21 October 2014}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The Daily Beast]]'', Jacob Siegel suggests that the perpetrator of [[2014 Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu ramming attack|the 2014 Couture-Rouleau attack]] may be "the kind of terrorist the West could be seeing a lot more of in the future", a kind that he describes, following Brian Jenkins of the [[Rand Corporation]], as "stray dogs", rather than [[Lone wolf (terrorism)|lone wolves]], characterizing them as "misfits" who are "moved from seething anger to spontaneous deadly action" by exposure to [[Islamist]] propaganda.<ref name="Daily Beast">{{cite news|last1=Siegel|first1=Jacob|title=Lone Wolves, Terrorist Runts, and the Stray Dogs of ISIS Why ISIS and al Qaeda rely on loners and losers to carry out their terrorist agenda in the West|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/10/24/in-canada-the-stray-dogs-of-isis.html|accessdate=7 November 2014|work=[[Daily Beast]]|date=24 October 2014|deadurl=no|archivedate=7 November 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107133653/http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/10/24/in-canada-the-stray-dogs-of-isis.html|df=dmy-all}}</ref> A 2014 propaganda video by [[ISIL]] encouraged French sympathizers to use cars to run down civilians.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/isis-al-qaeda-car-attacks-nice-france-2016-7|title=ISIS and Al Qaeda have specifically called for the type of attack that just happened in France|publisher=}}</ref>
According to [[Clint Watts]], of the [[Foreign Policy Research Institute]], where he is a senior fellow and expert on terrorism, the older model where members of groups like [[al-Qaeda]] would "plan and train together before going to carry out an attack, became defunct around 2005", due to increased surveillance by Western security agencies.<ref name="Daily Beast"/> Watts says that [[Anwar al-Awlaki]], the American born al-Qaeda [[imam]], as a key figure in this shift, addressing English-speakers in their own language and urging them to "Do your own terrorism and stay in place."<ref name="Daily Beast"/>
Jamie Bartlett, who heads the Violence and Extremism Program at [[Demos (UK think tank)|Demos]], a British think tank, explains that "the internet in the last few years has both increased the possibilities and the likelihood of lone-wolf terrorism," supplying isolated individuals with ideological motivation and technique.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|last1=Bajekal|first1=Naina|title=The Rise of the Lone Wolf Terrorist|url=http://time.com/3533581/canada-ottawa-shooting-lone-wolf-terrorism/|accessdate=6 November 2014|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time Magazine]]|date=23 October 2014|deadurl=no|archivedate=14 November 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141114150324/http://time.com/3533581/canada-ottawa-shooting-lone-wolf-terrorism/|df=dmy-all}}</ref> For authorities in Western countries, the difficulty is that even in a case like that of the perpetrator of the 2014 Couture-Rouleau attack, where Canadian police had identified the attacker, taken away his passport, and were working with his family and community to steer him away from [[jihad]], vehicle attacks can be hard to prevent because, "it's very difficult to know exactly what an individual is planning to do before a crime is committed. We cannot arrest someone for thinking radical thoughts; it's not a crime in Canada."<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Mataconis|first1=Doug|title=The attack on Canada's Parliament and the 'lone wolf' terrorist|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/DC-Decoder/Decoder-Voices/2014/1023/The-attack-on-Canada-s-Parliament-and-the-lone-wolf-terrorist|accessdate=6 November 2014|publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|date=23 October 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141106160115/http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/DC-Decoder/Decoder-Voices/2014/1023/The-attack-on-Canada-s-Parliament-and-the-lone-wolf-terrorist|archivedate=6 November 2014|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
According to [[Stratfor]], the American global intelligence firm, "while not thus far as deadly as [[suicide bombing]]", this tactic could prove more difficult to prevent. No single group has claimed responsibility for the incidents.<ref name=stratfor>Israel: Vehicle Attacks – A New Militant Tactic?. Stratfor Global Intelligence</ref>{{clarify|reason=Which incidents?|date=July 2016}} Experts see a sort of saving grace in the ignorance and incompetence of most lone wolf terrorists, who often manage to murder very few people.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
Vehicular ramming has sometimes been advocated as a means to deal with [[protester]]s who block public roadways in the United States. Two police officers were suspended and fired in January and June 2016, respectively, for tweeting such advice in relation to [[Black Lives Matter]] rallies, which have sometimes been broken up by cars. [[North Dakota]] state legislator [[Keith Kempenich]] tried and failed to pass a law granting civil immunity to drivers who accidentally hit activists, after his mother-in-law was stopped by [[Dakota Access Pipeline protests|Dakota Access Pipeline protesters]], and [[Tennessee]] Senator [[Bill Ketron]] did likewise after a man hit an [[Protests against Donald Trump|anti-Trump]] group. Similar legislation has been introduced in [[Florida]] and [[Texas]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Grabar|first=Henry|title="Run Them Down"|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/business/metropolis/2017/08/driving_into_crowds_of_protesters_was_a_right_wing_fantasy_long_before_charlottesville.html|publisher=[[Slate.com]]|date=August 14, 2017}}</ref> After the white supremacist [[Unite the Right rally]], in which a [[anti-fascist]] protestor was killed in a vehicle ramming attack, conservative media outlets [[Fox News]] and [[The Daily Caller]] deleted videos which encouraged driving through crowds of protestors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/08/15/media/daily-caller-fox-news-video-car-crashing-liberal-protesters/index.html|title=Fox News, Daily Caller delete posts encouraging people to drive through protests|last=Kludt|first=Tom|date=2017-08-15|website=CNNMoney|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref>
==Protective measures== [[Image:national.security.parliament.arp.750pix.Clean.jpg|thumb|Security measures taken to protect the [[Palace of Westminster|Houses of Parliament]] in [[London]], [[United Kingdom|UK]]. These heavy blocks of [[concrete]] are designed to prevent a [[car bomb]] or other device being rammed into the building.]] [[File:Postplatz Tag der Deutschen Einheit Dresden Sachsen Germany Nizza Sperre 0x.jpg|thumb|Concrete blocks in the city centre of [[Dresden]] during the 2016 [[German Unity Day|German Unity Day Celebrations]]]] On 23 October 2014, the US [[National Institute of Building Sciences]] updated its Building Design Guideline on ''Crash- and Attack-Resistant Models'' of [[bollard]]s, a guideline written to help professionals design bollards to protect facilities from vehicle operators, "who plan or carry out acts of property destruction, incite terrorism, or cause the deaths of civilian, industrial or military populations".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Oakes|first=Charles|title=The Bollard: Crash- and Attack-Resistant Models|journal=Whole Building Design Guide, National Institute of Building Sciences|date=23 October 2014|url=http://www.wbdg.org/resources/bollard_arm.php|accessdate=7 November 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107170018/http://www.wbdg.org/resources/bollard_arm.php|archivedate=7 November 2014|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[American Bar Association]] recommends bollards as effective protection against car ramming attacks.<ref>Ernest B. Abbott and Otto J. Hetzel, "Homeland Security Begins at Home: Local Planning and Regulatory Review to Improve Security", in Rufus Calhoun Young, Jr. and Dwight H. Merriam, ''A Legal Guide to Homeland Security and Emergency Management for State and Local Governments'', American Bar Association, 2006</ref>
Security bollards are credited with minimizing damage and casualties in the [[2007 Glasgow Airport attack]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Garfield|first=Simon|title=Terrorists are foiled at Glasgow airport|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2007/dec/23/features.magazine327|accessdate=7 November 2014|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=7 December 2007|archivedate=7 November 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107174910/http://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2007/dec/23/features.magazine327|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Glasgow airport ramps up use of bollards|url=http://www.securityinfowatch.com/news/10496575/glasgow-airport-ramps-up-use-of-bollards|accessdate=7 November 2014|work=[[Glasgow Evening Times]]|date=22 December 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107175646/http://www.securityinfowatch.com/news/10496575/glasgow-airport-ramps-up-use-of-bollards|archivedate=7 November 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and with preventing ramming in the [[2014 Alon Shvut stabbing attack]], leading the assailant to abandon his car and attack pedestrians waiting at a bus stop with a knife, after his effort to run them over was thwarted.<ref>{{cite news|last=Tait|first=Robert|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/11221592/Israeli-woman-25-and-soldier-killed-in-twin-stabbing-attacks.html|accessdate=11 November 2014|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=10 November 2014|title=Israeli woman, 25, and soldier killed in twin stabbing attacks – Incidents happen hours apart, suggesting an escalation of recent violence|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141111025044/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/11221592/Israeli-woman-25-and-soldier-killed-in-twin-stabbing-attacks.html|archivedate=11 November 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, Berlin's police chief, Klaus Kandt, argued that bollards would not have prevented the 2016 Berlin attack, and that the required security measures would be "varied, complex, and far from a panacea".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Halliday|first1=Josh|last2=Perraudin|first2=Frances|title=What can be done to prevent Berlin-style attacks in modern cities?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/dec/20/what-can-be-done-to-prevent-berlin-style-attacks-in-modern-cities|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=22 January 2017|date=20 December 2016}}</ref>
The city of Münster has been planning to install security bollards in public areas in response to vehicle-ramming attacks in European cities, including the [[2016 Berlin attack]].<ref name="Bollards">{{cite news|title=Do bollards offer protection against vehicle attacks?|url=http://www.dw.com/en/do-bollards-offer-protection-against-vehicle-attacks/a-43300057|accessdate=8 April 2018|publisher=DW|date=8 March 2018}}</ref> While only selected locations can be protected this way, tight bends and restricted-width streets may also prevent a large vehicle getting speed before reaching a barrier.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://i-hls.com/2017/01/vehicle-ramming-attacks-security-measures/|title=Vehicle Ramming Attacks - Are There Any Security Measures? - iHLS|first=iHLS News|last=Desk|date=9 January 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
Modern [[Internet]]-connected [[drive-by-wire]] cars can potentially be [[remote exploit|hacked]] remotely and used for such attacks. In 2015, hackers remotely carjacked a Jeep from 10 miles away and drove it into a ditch.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=Hackers Remotely Kill a Jeep on the Highway—With Me in It|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/07/hackers-remotely-kill-jeep-highway/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hackers take control of car, drive it into a ditch|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/hackers-remotely-carjack-jeep-from-10-miles-away-and-drive-it-into-ditch-10406554.html|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=22 January 2017|date=22 July 2015}}</ref> Measures for [[Computer security#Automobiles|cybersecurity of automobiles]] to prevent such are often criticized as to being insufficient.{{fact|date=September 2018}}
==List of terrorist attacks== {{Expand list|date=November 2016}}
In chronological order:
* [[1981 Iraqi embassy bombing]], [[Beirut]], [[Lebanon]] (not ramming pedestrians: ramming a specific building then exploding) * [[1983 Beirut barracks bombings]], Lebanon (building ramming + exploding) * [[Captain Miller|1987 Army camp bombing]], Sri Lanka (building ramming + exploding) * [[1998 Temple of the Tooth attack]], Sri Lanka (building ramming + exploding) * [[Ibar Highway assassination attempt|1999 Ibar Highway assassination attempt]], FR Yugoslavia (assassination attempt) * [[2001 Azor attack]], Israel (ramming people, mostly soldiers) * [[2001 Jammu and Kashmir legislative assembly car bombing]] (building gate ramming + exploding + gunfire) * [[2002 Lyon car attack]], [[France]] (building ramming + fire) * [[Marvin Heemeyer|2004 Granby Colorado rampage]] (modified bulldozer) * [[2006 UNC SUV attack]], [[University of North Carolina]], [[United States]] (ramming people) * [[2007 Glasgow International Airport attack]], [[Scotland]], [[United Kingdom]] (building ramming + detonating gas cylinders) * [[2008 Jerusalem vehicular attack]], [[Israel]] (ramming vehicles and people) * [[2008 Jerusalem bulldozer attack]], Israel (ramming people) * [[2011 Tel Aviv truck attack]], Israel (ramming vehicles and people) * [[2011 Tel Aviv nightclub attack]], Israel (ramming + stabbing) * May 2013 [[Murder of Lee Rigby]], [[London]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom]] (ramming + stabbing) * [[2013 Tiananmen Square attack]], [[China]] (ramming people + bursting into flames) * [[May 2014 Ürümqi attack]], China (ramming + throwing bombs off the vehicle) * [[2014 Jerusalem tractor attack]], Israel (ramming people + bus) * [[2014 Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu ramming attack]], [[Canada]] (ramming) * [[October 2014 Jerusalem vehicular attack]], Israel (ramming people) * [[November 2014 Jerusalem vehicular attack]], Israel (ramming + hitting with a metal crowbar) * [[2014 Alon Shvut stabbing attack]], [[West Bank]] (failed ramming + stabbing) * [[2016 Nice
